verses.text: The record of the origin of Jesus the Messiah, son of David, son of Abraham.
Abraham fathered Isaac, Isaac fathered Jacob, Jacob fathered Judah and his brothers,
Judah fathered Perez and Zerah by Tamar, Perez fathered Hezron, Hezron fathered Ram,
Ram fathered Amminadab, Amminadab fathered Nahshon, Nahshon fathered Salmon,
Salmon fathered Boaz by Rahab, Boaz fathered Obed by Ruth, Obed fathered Jesse,
and Jesse fathered David the king. David fathered Solomon by the wife of Uriah,
Solomon fathered Rehoboam, Rehoboam fathered Abijah, Abijah fathered Asaph,
Asaph fathered Jehoshaphat, Jehoshaphat fathered Joram, Joram fathered Uzziah,
Uzziah fathered Jotham, Jotham fathered Ahaz, Ahaz fathered Hezekiah,
Hezekiah fathered Manasseh, Manasseh fathered Amos, Amos fathered Josiah,
and Josiah fathered Jeconiah and his brothers at the time of the deportation to Babylon.
After the deportation to Babylon, Jeconiah fathered Shealtiel, Shealtiel fathered Zerubbabel,
Zerubbabel fathered Abiud, Abiud fathered Eliakim, Eliakim fathered Azor,
Azor fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Achim, Achim fathered Eliud,
Eliud fathered Eleazar, Eleazar fathered Matthan, Matthan fathered Jacob,
and Jacob fathered Joseph the husband of Mary, from whom was born Jesus, the one called the Messiah.

So all the generations from Abraham to David are fourteen generations, from David to the deportation to Babylon fourteen generations, and from the deportation to Babylon to the Messiah fourteen generations.
Now the origin of Jesus the Messiah came about this way: When his mother Mary had been betrothed to Joseph, before they came together she was found to be carrying a child from the Holy Spirit.
But Joseph her husband, being a righteous man and not wanting to expose her to public disgrace, resolved to divorce her quietly.

While he was considering these things, look—an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream, saying, "Joseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary as your wife, for what has been conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit.
She will bear a son, and you shall call his name Jesus, for he will save his people from their sins."
All this took place so that what was spoken by the Lord through the prophet might be fulfilled:
"Look, the virgin will conceive and bear a son, and they will call his name Emmanuel"—which translated means, "God with us."
When Joseph rose from sleep, he did as the angel of the Lord commanded him and took his wife into his home,
but he did not know her until she bore a son. And he called his name Jesus.

chapters.notes:
**"Record of the origin" (v. 1)**: The Greek βίβλος γενέσεως deliberately echoes Genesis 2:4 and 5:1 in the Septuagint. The word γένεσις means origin, beginning, or coming-into-being—not merely "genealogy." Matthew signals that this is a new Genesis narrative. The same word recurs in v. 18, creating a frame: v. 1 introduces the record of Jesus's origin through his lineage, v. 18 introduces the story of his actual origin.

**"Messiah" (vv. 1, 16, 17, 18)**: Greek χριστός translates Hebrew *mashiach* (anointed one). First-century readers understood this as a title denoting the expected Davidic king, not a personal name. Using "Messiah" rather than "Christ" recovers this.

**"The wife of Uriah" (v. 6)**: The Greek pointedly does not name Bathsheba, calling her only τῆς τοῦ Οὐρίου—"the [wife] of Uriah." This keeps David's adultery and murder in view.

**"Asaph" and "Amos" (vv. 7-8, 10)**: The critical text reads Ἀσάφ and Ἀμώς rather than the expected "Asa" and "Amon." These appear to be the names of the famous psalm-writer and prophet. Whether this reflects scribal error or Matthew's intentional wordplay linking the royal line to prophetic/musical figures remains debated; the translation follows the earliest manuscripts.

**"Betrothed" (v. 18)**: Jewish betrothal was legally binding—the woman was already her husband's wife (hence ἀνήρ for Joseph in v. 19), though they had not yet cohabited. Ending a betrothal required formal divorce.

**"Did not know her" (v. 25)**: This Semitic idiom for sexual relations (from Hebrew *yada*) is preserved here because it echoes the language of Genesis and carries a certain gravity that "did not have relations with her" lacks.

**Verse 16's structural break**: Throughout the genealogy, the verb ἐγέννησεν (fathered) is active. At v. 16, the pattern breaks: Joseph is not said to have fathered Jesus. Instead, the passive ἐγεννήθη (was born) appears with a feminine relative pronoun (ἐξ ἧς) clearly referring to Mary. The grammar itself makes a theological claim about Jesus's conception.

verses.text: After Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea during the days of King Herod, suddenly magi from the east arrived in Jerusalem,
asking, "Where is the one who has been born king of the Jews? For we saw his star at its rising and have come to pay him homage."
When King Herod heard this, he was deeply disturbed, and all Jerusalem with him.
Gathering together all the chief priests and scribes of the people, he inquired of them where the Messiah was to be born.
They told him, "In Bethlehem of Judea, for so it stands written through the prophet:
*And you, Bethlehem, land of Judah, are by no means least among the rulers of Judah; for from you will come forth a ruler who will shepherd my people Israel.*"
Then Herod secretly summoned the magi and determined from them precisely when the star had appeared.
Sending them to Bethlehem, he said, "Go and search carefully for the child. When you find him, report back to me so that I too may come and pay him homage."
After hearing the king, they went on their way, and suddenly the star they had seen at its rising went ahead of them until it came and stood over the place where the child was.
When they saw the star, they were overwhelmed with joy.

Coming into the house, they saw the child with Mary his mother, and falling down they paid him homage. Then, opening their treasure chests, they presented him with gifts: gold, frankincense, and myrrh.
And having been warned in a dream not to return to Herod, they departed for their own country by another road.

After they had departed, suddenly an angel of the Lord appears to Joseph in a dream, saying, "Rise, take the child and his mother, and flee to Egypt. Remain there until I tell you, for Herod is about to search for the child to destroy him."
So he rose, took the child and his mother by night, and withdrew to Egypt.
He remained there until the death of Herod, so that what was spoken by the Lord through the prophet might be fulfilled: *Out of Egypt I called my son.*

Then Herod, seeing that he had been outwitted by the magi, flew into a violent rage. He sent and killed all the boys in Bethlehem and in all its surrounding region who were two years old and under, according to the time he had determined precisely from the magi.
Then what was spoken through Jeremiah the prophet was fulfilled:
*A voice was heard in Ramah, weeping and bitter lamentation—Rachel weeping for her children, and she would not be comforted, because they are no more.*
After Herod died, suddenly an angel of the Lord appears in a dream to Joseph in Egypt,
saying, "Rise, take the child and his mother, and go to the land of Israel, for those who were seeking the child's life have died."
So he rose, took the child and his mother, and entered the land of Israel.
But hearing that Archelaus was reigning over Judea in place of his father Herod, he was afraid to go there. And having been warned in a dream, he withdrew to the region of Galilee.
He went and settled in a town called Nazareth, so that what was spoken through the prophets might be fulfilled: "He will be called a Nazorean."

chapters.notes:
**"Magi" (v. 1, 7, 16)**: I retain "magi" rather than "wise men" because it more accurately identifies this specific class of Persian/Babylonian priest-scholars known for astrology and dream interpretation. The term carries cultural specificity that "wise men" loses.

**"At its rising" (v. 2, 9)**: The singular ἐν τῇ ἀνατολῇ likely means "at its rising" (an astronomical term for a star's first appearance) rather than "in the east" (which uses the plural ἀπὸ ἀνατολῶν in v. 1). This reading fits the context of stargazers observing celestial phenomena.

**"Pay him homage" (v. 2, 8, 11)**: The Greek προσκυνέω can mean either political homage to royalty or religious worship. Since the magi understand Jesus as "king of the Jews" (a political title), "pay homage" better captures the ambiguity—though Matthew's readers would understand a deeper significance.

**"Overwhelmed with joy" (v. 10)**: The Greek ἐχάρησαν χαρὰν μεγάλην σφόδρα is a cognate accusative construction ("they rejoiced with exceedingly great joy")—a Semitic intensification pattern. "Overwhelmed with joy" attempts to convey this emphatic piling up of joy-language.

**"Appears" (v. 13, 19)**: The historic present tense (φαίνεται) creates narrative vividness. I preserve this where it occurs.

**"Those who were seeking the child's life have died" (v. 20)**: This echoes Exodus 4:19 (LXX), where God tells Moses "those seeking your life have died." Matthew signals that Jesus is a new Moses figure returning from Egypt. The plural "those" may allude to this text even though only Herod is in view.

**"Nazorean" (v. 23)**: I use "Nazorean" (from Ναζωραῖος) rather than "Nazarene" to preserve the ambiguity. Matthew cites "the prophets" (plural, unusually), suggesting a thematic fulfillment rather than a direct quotation. Scholars propose connections to Hebrew נֵצֶר (branch, Isaiah 11:1) or נָזִיר (Nazirite, or possibly "separated/despised one"). The wordplay is intentional and cannot be fully captured in translation.

**"So that...might be fulfilled" vs. "Then...was fulfilled" (v. 15, 17)**: Matthew uses two different fulfillment formulas: ἵνα πληρωθῇ (purpose, v. 15, 23) and τότε ἐπληρώθη (result, v. 17). The massacre fulfillment lacks the purposive ἵνα, perhaps indicating Matthew saw this not as God's purpose but as tragic correspondence.

verses.text: In those days, John the Baptizer appears, proclaiming in the wilderness of Judea
and saying, "Turn back! For the kingdom of the heavens has drawn near."
This is the one spoken of through Isaiah the prophet, who said: "A voice crying out in the wilderness: Prepare the way of the Lord, make his paths straight."
Now John himself wore clothing made of camel's hair with a leather belt around his waist, and his food was locusts and wild honey.
Then Jerusalem and all Judea and the whole region around the Jordan kept going out to him,
and they were being baptized by him in the Jordan River as they openly confessed their sins.
But when he saw many of the Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, he said to them, "Brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath?
Produce fruit worthy of your turning,
and do not presume to say among yourselves, 'We have Abraham as our father.' For I tell you that God is able to raise up children for Abraham from these stones.
Already the axe is laid at the root of the trees. So every tree that does not produce good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.
"I baptize you in water for turning. But the one coming after me is more powerful than I—I am not fit to carry his sandals. He will baptize you in holy spirit and fire.
His winnowing fork is in his hand, and he will thoroughly clean his threshing floor. He will gather his grain into the storehouse, but the chaff he will burn with unquenchable fire."
Then Jesus arrives from Galilee at the Jordan, coming to John to be baptized by him.
But John kept trying to prevent him, saying, "I need to be baptized by you, and you are coming to me?"
But Jesus answered him, "Permit it for now, for in this way it is fitting for us to fulfill all righteousness." Then he permitted him.
When Jesus had been baptized, he immediately came up from the water—and look: the heavens were opened, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove, coming upon him.
And look: a voice from the heavens, saying, "This is my Son, the Beloved, in whom I delight."

chapters.notes:
**"Turn back" / "turning" (vv. 2, 8, 11)**: The Greek μετανοέω/μετάνοια literally means "change of mind," but in Jewish usage it carries the full weight of the Hebrew *teshuvah*—returning to God. Modern "repent" often implies mere remorse or regret. "Turn back" captures the directional, active sense: reorienting one's life toward God.

**"Has drawn near" (v. 2)**: The perfect tense ἤγγικεν indicates completed action with ongoing results—the kingdom has arrived at the threshold and remains there. This is more urgent than the traditional "is at hand."

**"Kingdom of the heavens" (v. 2)**: Matthew consistently uses "heavens" (plural) where Mark and Luke use "God," reflecting Jewish reverence that avoided speaking God's name directly. I preserve Matthew's distinctive phrasing.

**"Kept going out" / "kept trying to prevent" (vv. 5, 14)**: The imperfect tense in Greek indicates ongoing or repeated action. In v. 5, it shows crowds continually streaming out; in v. 14, it shows John's persistent resistance (a conative imperfect—he was attempting but not succeeding).

**"From these stones... children" (v. 9)**: In Hebrew/Aramaic, there is wordplay between *avanim* (stones) and *banim* (sons/children). A first-century Jewish audience would catch this resonance.

**"Fit to carry his sandals" (v. 11)**: ἱκανός means worthy or fit for a task. Carrying sandals was work too menial even for disciples—it was a slave's duty. John claims a status lower than a slave in relation to the coming one.

**"In holy spirit and fire" (v. 11)**: I leave "spirit" lowercase because the phrase parallels "water" and "fire" as baptismal elements. Whether this denotes the Holy Spirit specifically or a refining spiritual force is genuinely ambiguous in the text.

**"Look" (vv. 16, 17)**: ἰδού is a dramatic interjection demanding attention. "Behold" sounds archaic; "look" preserves the immediacy and impact.

**"The Beloved" (v. 17)**: ὁ ἀγαπητός functions as a title, echoing both Psalm 2:7 (the messianic king) and the description of Isaac in Genesis 22 (LXX). This may signal Jesus as both royal heir and beloved son to be offered.

**"In whom I delight" (v. 17)**: εὐδοκέω means to take pleasure or delight in. "Delight" is stronger and more intimate than the traditional "well pleased" and better echoes the language of Isaiah 42:1, the servant in whom God delights.

verses.text: Then Jesus was led up into the wilderness by the Spirit to be tested by the devil.
And after fasting forty days and forty nights, he was hungry.
The tester approached and said to him, "If you are God's Son, command these stones to become bread."
But he answered, "It is written: 'A person will not live on bread alone, but on every word that comes forth from the mouth of God.'"
Then the devil took him to the holy city and stood him on the highest point of the temple,

and said to him, "If you are God's Son, throw yourself down. For it is written: 'He will command his angels concerning you,' and 'On their hands they will lift you up, so that you never strike your foot against a stone.'"
Jesus said to him, "Again it is written: 'You shall not put the Lord your God to the test.'"
Again the devil took him to an exceedingly high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and their splendor,
and said to him, "All these I will give you, if you will fall down and worship me."
Then Jesus said to him, "Be gone, Satan! For it is written: 'The Lord your God you shall worship, and him alone you shall serve.'"
Then the devil left him, and look—angels came and began ministering to him.
Now when he heard that John had been handed over, he withdrew to Galilee.
And leaving Nazareth, he went and settled in Capernaum by the sea, in the territory of Zebulun and Naphtali,
so that what was spoken through Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled:
"Land of Zebulun and land of Naphtali, the way to the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations—
the people sitting in darkness have seen a great light, and for those sitting in the region and shadow of death, a light has dawned for them."
From that time Jesus began to proclaim and say, "Turn back, for the kingdom of the heavens has come near."
Walking along the Sea of Galilee, he saw two brothers—Simon, the one called Peter, and Andrew his brother—casting a net into the sea, for they were fishermen.
And he said to them, "Come, follow me, and I will make you fishers of people."
Immediately they left their nets and followed him.
Going on from there, he saw two other brothers—James the son of Zebedee and John his brother—in the boat with Zebedee their father, mending their nets. And he called them.
Immediately they left the boat and their father and followed him.
And he went throughout all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues and proclaiming the good news of the kingdom and healing every disease and every affliction among the people.

And the report about him spread into all Syria, and they brought to him all who were suffering—those gripped by various diseases and severe pains, those possessed by demons, epileptics, and paralytics—and he healed them.
And large crowds followed him from Galilee and the Decapolis and Jerusalem and Judea and from beyond the Jordan.

chapters.notes:
**"Tested" (v. 1, 3)**: Greek πειράζω can mean either "test" or "tempt." The wilderness setting deliberately echoes Israel's forty-year testing in the wilderness (Deuteronomy 8:2), where the same Greek verb is used in the Septuagint. "Test" captures this resonance better than "tempt," which in modern English implies enticement to sin. The devil is testing whether Jesus will be a faithful Son where Israel was not.

**"If you are God's Son" (v. 3, 6)**: The Greek lacks the article ("Son of God" not "the Son of God"). The first-class conditional (Εἰ + indicative) does not express doubt but assumes the condition for argument's sake—"given that you are..." However, English "if" captures this construction adequately, as the devil is challenging Jesus to prove his identity.

**"Handed over" (v. 12)**: Greek παραδίδωμι. Most translations render this "arrested," but the verb specifically means "handed over" or "delivered up"—the same word used repeatedly for Jesus's betrayal and passion. Matthew's use of this loaded term for John foreshadows what awaits Jesus.

**"Turn back" (v. 17)**: Greek μετανοεῖτε is typically rendered "repent." While not wrong, "repent" in modern English often suggests feeling sorry for sins. The underlying Hebrew concept (תְּשׁוּבָה, teshuvah) means turning back—reorienting one's entire life toward God. "Turn back" recovers this directional, whole-life sense.

**"Kingdom of the heavens" (v. 17)**: Matthew consistently uses this phrase (βασιλεία τῶν οὐρανῶν) rather than Mark and Luke's "kingdom of God"—a Jewish circumlocution avoiding direct use of God's name. Preserving "heavens" (plural, as in Greek) maintains Matthew's distinctive voice.

**"Epileptics" (v. 24)**: Greek σεληνιαζομένους literally means "moon-struck"—ancients associated epileptic seizures with lunar phases. A literal rendering ("those affected by the moon") would confuse modern readers; "epileptics" conveys what the original audience understood.

**"Severe pains" (v. 24)**: Greek βάσανος originally meant a touchstone for testing metals, then came to mean torture, then intense pain. "Torments" preserves the intensity but sounds archaic; "severe pains" captures the meaning accessibly.

verses.text: When he saw the crowds, he went up onto the mountain, and when he had sat down, his disciples came to him.
And opening his mouth, he began teaching them, saying:
"Blessed are the destitute in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of the heavens.
Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted.
Blessed are those gentle in strength, for they will inherit the earth.
Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for justice, for they will be satisfied.
Blessed are the merciful, for they will receive mercy.
Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God.
Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called sons of God.
Blessed are those who have been persecuted on account of justice, for theirs is the kingdom of the heavens.
"Blessed are you when people insult you and persecute you and say every kind of evil against you falsely on my account.
Rejoice and be overjoyed, because your reward is great in the heavens—for this is how they persecuted the prophets who came before you.
"You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt becomes foolish, with what will it be made salty? It is no longer good for anything except to be thrown out and trampled underfoot by people.
"You are the light of the world. A city situated on a hill cannot be hidden.
Nor do people light a lamp and put it under a measuring basket, but on the lampstand, and it gives light to everyone in the house.
In the same way, let your light shine before people, so that they may see your good works and glorify your Father who is in the heavens.
"Do not think that I came to abolish the Law or the Prophets. I did not come to abolish but to fulfill.
For truly I tell you, until heaven and earth pass away, not one iota or one stroke will pass away from the Law until all things come to pass.

Therefore, whoever relaxes one of the least of these commandments and teaches others to do so will be called least in the kingdom of the heavens. But whoever practices and teaches them—this one will be called great in the kingdom of the heavens.
For I tell you that unless your righteousness far exceeds that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will never enter the kingdom of the heavens.
"You have heard that it was said to the ancients, 'You shall not murder,' and 'Whoever murders will be liable to judgment.'

But I say to you that everyone who is angry with his brother will be liable to judgment. And whoever says to his brother 'Raka!' will be liable to the Sanhedrin. And whoever says 'You fool!' will be liable to the Gehenna of fire.
"So if you are bringing your gift to the altar and there you remember that your brother has something against you,
leave your gift there before the altar and go. First be reconciled to your brother, and then come and offer your gift.
"Come to terms quickly with your accuser while you are still with him on the road, or your accuser may hand you over to the judge, and the judge to the officer, and you will be thrown into prison.
Truly I tell you, you will never get out of there until you have paid the last quadrans.
"You have heard that it was said, 'You shall not commit adultery.'
But I say to you that everyone who looks at a woman in order to desire her has already committed adultery with her in his heart.
"If your right eye causes you to stumble, tear it out and throw it away from you. For it is better for you that one of your members should perish than for your whole body to be thrown into Gehenna.
And if your right hand causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away from you. For it is better for you that one of your members should perish than for your whole body to go into Gehenna.
"It was said, 'Whoever divorces his wife must give her a certificate of divorce.'
But I say to you that everyone who divorces his wife, except on the grounds of sexual immorality, makes her commit adultery, and whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.
"Again, you have heard that it was said to the ancients, 'You shall not swear falsely, but shall fulfill your oaths to the Lord.'
But I say to you, do not swear at all—not by heaven, for it is the throne of God;
not by the earth, for it is the footstool of his feet; not by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King;
and do not swear by your head, for you cannot make one hair white or black.
Let your word be 'Yes, yes' or 'No, no.' Anything beyond this comes from the evil one.
"You have heard that it was said, 'Eye for eye and tooth for tooth.'
But I say to you, do not resist the evildoer. Rather, whoever strikes you on the right cheek, turn to him the other also.
And if someone wants to sue you and take your tunic, let him have your cloak as well.
And whoever conscripts you for one mile, go with him two.
Give to the one who asks you, and do not turn away from the one who wants to borrow from you.
"You have heard that it was said, 'You shall love your neighbor' and 'You shall hate your enemy.'
But I say to you, love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you,
so that you may become sons of your Father who is in the heavens—for he makes his sun rise on the wicked and the good, and sends rain on the just and the unjust.
For if you love those who love you, what reward do you have? Do not even the tax collectors do the same?
And if you greet only your brothers, what more are you doing? Do not even the Gentiles do the same?
Therefore you shall be complete, as your heavenly Father is complete."

chapters.notes:
**"Destitute" (v. 3)**: Greek πτωχός refers not to modest means but to begging poverty—those with nothing. This is stronger than "poor" in modern English, which can suggest merely limited resources.

**"Gentle in strength" (v. 5)**: Greek πραεῖς (often translated "meek") doesn't mean weakness or passivity. It describes controlled strength—power held in check, like a war horse trained for battle but responsive to its rider. The word implies having the capacity for force but choosing restraint and gentleness instead.

**"Justice/righteousness" (vv. 6, 10, 20)**: Greek δικαιοσύνη encompasses both personal righteousness and social justice. I use "justice" in vv. 6 and 10 where the hunger is for God's setting-right of the world, and "righteousness" in v. 20 where personal conduct is in view.

**"Becomes foolish" (v. 13)**: Greek μωρανθῇ literally means "become foolish." This likely reflects an Aramaic wordplay where תָּפֵל (tāpēl) means both "foolish" and "unsalted/tasteless." Rather than flatten to "loses its saltiness," I preserve the Greek's unusual word choice.

**"Raka" (v. 22)**: Aramaic term of contempt (רֵיקָא) meaning "empty one" or "worthless." Retained as a transliteration since it was already a foreign word to Greek readers.

**"Quadrans" (v. 26)**: The smallest Roman coin, worth 1/64 of a denarius. Retaining the term preserves the precision of the original—every last fraction must be paid.

**"Causes you to stumble" (vv. 29-30)**: Greek σκανδαλίζει derives from σκάνδαλον, the trigger of a trap. The meaning is causing someone to fall into sin, not merely offense or annoyance.

**"Conscripts" (v. 41)**: Greek ἀγγαρεύσει is a Persian loanword for compulsory service—being forced to carry a soldier's pack. "Forces you to go" misses the specific context of imperial requisition.

**"Complete" (v. 48)**: Greek τέλειος means whole, mature, or having reached one's end/purpose—not "perfect" in the sense of flawless. The call is to be whole in love as God is whole, not to achieve moral perfection.

verses.text: Be careful not to practice your righteousness before others in order to be watched by them. Otherwise, you have no reward with your Father who is in the heavens.

So when you give to the poor, do not sound a trumpet before you, as the performers do in the synagogues and in the streets so that they may be praised by others. Truly I tell you: they have been paid in full.
But when you give to the poor, do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing,
so that your giving may be in secret. And your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will repay you.

And when you pray, do not be like the performers, for they love to pray standing in the synagogues and at the corners of the main streets so that they may be seen by others. Truly I tell you: they have been paid in full.
But when you pray, go into your inner room and shut your door and pray to your Father who is in the hidden place. And your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will repay you.
And when you pray, do not babble on like the pagans, for they think that they will be heard because of their many words.
Do not be like them, for your Father knows what you need before you ask him.
Pray, then, like this: Our Father in the heavens, let your name be held holy,
let your kingdom come, let your will be done, as in heaven, so also on earth.
Give us today our bread for the coming day,
and release us from our debts, as we also have released our debtors.
And do not bring us into the time of trial, but rescue us from the evil one.
For if you release others from their transgressions, your heavenly Father will also release you.
But if you do not release others, neither will your Father release your transgressions.
And when you fast, do not be gloomy like the performers, for they disfigure their faces so that their fasting may be visible to others. Truly I tell you: they have been paid in full.
But when you fast, anoint your head and wash your face,
so that your fasting may not be visible to others but only to your Father who is in the hidden place. And your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will repay you.
Do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth, where moth and decay destroy, and where thieves dig through and steal.
Rather, store up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor decay destroys, and where thieves do not dig through or steal.
For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.
The eye is the lamp of the body. If your eye is generous, your whole body will be full of light.
But if your eye is stingy, your whole body will be full of darkness. If then the light within you is darkness, how great is that darkness!
No one can serve as a slave to two masters. For either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and Mammon.
For this reason I tell you: do not be anxious about your life—what you will eat—or about your body—what you will wear. Is not life more than food, and the body more than clothing?
Look at the birds of the sky: they do not sow or reap or gather into barns, and yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not worth far more than they?
And which of you by being anxious can add a single hour to the span of your life?
And why are you anxious about clothing? Consider the wildflowers of the field, how they grow: they do not toil or spin.
Yet I tell you that not even Solomon in all his splendor was clothed like one of these.
Now if God so clothes the grass of the field, which is here today and tomorrow is thrown into the oven, will he not much more clothe you, you of little faith?
So do not be anxious, saying, "What will we eat?" or "What will we drink?" or "What will we wear?"
For the pagans chase after all these things, and your heavenly Father knows that you need them all.
But seek first the kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.
So do not be anxious about tomorrow, for tomorrow will be anxious for itself. Each day has enough trouble of its own.

chapters.notes:
**"Performers" (v. 2, 5, 16)**: Greek ὑποκριταί originally referred to stage actors—people playing a role for an audience. The modern "hypocrite" suggests someone whose private beliefs contradict their public actions. Jesus's critique is sharper: these people's religion *is* the performance; the audience is the point.

**"Paid in full" (v. 2, 5, 16)**: The verb ἀπέχουσιν is commercial terminology—what appears on a receipt when a debt is settled. The transaction is complete; no further payment is coming.

**"Inner room" (v. 6)**: Greek ταμεῖον refers to a storeroom or storage chamber—the innermost, most private space in an ancient house, often without windows. This contrasts maximally with the public street corners of v. 5.

**"Bread for the coming day" (v. 11)**: The word ἐπιούσιον appears nowhere else in Greek literature and may have been coined here. Its meaning is debated, but Jerome reported that the lost Gospel of the Hebrews had the Aramaic word for "tomorrow" here. "Bread for the coming day" fits the passage's theme about not worrying about tomorrow (v. 34) and echoes the manna provision (Exodus 16), which came daily and could not be hoarded.

**"Release...debts/debtors" (v. 12)**: Greek ὀφειλήματα/ὀφειλέταις literally means debts and debtors. The Aramaic word ḥôbâ underlying this can mean both financial debt and moral/spiritual obligation. I retained the economic language because it connects to the surrounding teaching about treasure and Mammon.

**"The evil one" (v. 13)**: Greek τοῦ πονηροῦ could be neuter ("evil") or masculine ("the evil one"). The presence of the article and the personified language of "testing" suggest the masculine reading.

**"Disfigure...visible" (v. 16)**: The Greek contains wordplay: ἀφανίζουσιν (make unsightly/unseen) and φανῶσιν (be seen/visible). They make their faces *un*-seen so that they may be *seen*. Capturing this paradox requires some interpretation; I've used "disfigure" and "visible."

**"Generous/stingy eye" (v. 22-23)**: Greek ἁπλοῦς (simple, single) and πονηρός (evil, bad) in reference to the eye directly invoke the Hebrew idiom: a "good eye" (עין טובה) means generosity, while an "evil eye" (עין רעה) means stinginess. This is not about physical vision but about one's disposition toward wealth and others. Translating as "generous" and "stingy" makes the connection to the surrounding context about treasure and Mammon explicit, as the original audience would have understood it.

**"Mammon" (v. 24)**: This is the Aramaic word ממון (mamōnā) transliterated into Greek. Rather than translating it as "money" or "wealth," I've preserved the foreign term because Jesus personifies it as a rival master demanding allegiance—giving it the weight of an alternative deity.

**"Span of your life" (v. 27)**: Greek ἡλικία can mean either "stature" (height) or "lifespan." The word πῆχυς (cubit, about 18 inches) creates an odd image if applied to height but works as a metaphor for a small unit of time. The context of anxiety about survival supports "lifespan."

**"Wildflowers" (v. 28)**: Greek κρίνα is traditionally "lilies," but likely refers to wildflowers generally—the colorful blooms that appear briefly in Galilean fields before the grass is cut for fuel.

verses.text: Do not condemn, so that you may not be condemned.
For by whatever judgment you judge, you will be judged, and by whatever measure you measure, it will be measured back to you.
Why do you see the splinter in your brother's eye, but fail to notice the beam in your own eye?
Or how will you say to your brother, "Let me take the splinter out of your eye," when look—there is a beam in your own eye?
Performer! First take the beam out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to take the splinter out of your brother's eye.
Do not give what is holy to the dogs, and do not throw your pearls before the pigs—otherwise they will trample them under their feet and then turn and tear you apart.
Ask, and it will be given to you. Seek, and you will find. Knock, and the door will be opened for you.
For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks it will be opened.
Or what person among you, if his son asks for bread—will give him a stone?
Or if he asks for a fish—will give him a snake?
If you, then, though you are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father who is in the heavens give good things to those who ask him!
So then, whatever you want people to do for you, do the same for them—for this is the Law and the Prophets.
Enter through the narrow gate. For wide is the gate and spacious is the road that leads away to destruction, and many are those who enter through it.
How narrow is the gate and constricted is the road that leads away to life, and few are those who find it!
Beware of the false prophets who come to you in sheep's clothing but inwardly are ravenous wolves.
By their fruits you will recognize them. Do people gather grapes from thornbushes, or figs from thistles?
In the same way, every good tree produces fine fruit, but a rotten tree produces bad fruit.
A good tree cannot produce bad fruit, nor can a rotten tree produce fine fruit.
Every tree that does not produce fine fruit is cut down and thrown into fire.
So then, by their fruits you will recognize them.
Not everyone who says to me, "Lord, Lord," will enter into the kingdom of the heavens, but the one who does the will of my Father who is in the heavens.
Many will say to me on that day, "Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and cast out demons in your name, and perform many powerful deeds in your name?"
And then I will declare to them: "I never knew you. Depart from me, you workers of lawlessness."
Everyone, therefore, who hears these words of mine and does them will be like a wise man who built his house on the rock.
And the rain came down, and the rivers rose, and the winds blew and beat against that house—and it did not fall, for it had been founded on the rock.
And everyone who hears these words of mine and does not do them will be like a foolish man who built his house on the sand.
And the rain came down, and the rivers rose, and the winds blew and struck against that house—and it fell, and great was its collapse.
And it happened that when Jesus finished these words, the crowds were astonished at his teaching,
for he was teaching them as one who has authority, and not as their scribes.

chapters.notes:
**"Condemn" (v. 1-2)**: While κρίνω can mean "judge" broadly, the context—with its warning about receiving the same treatment back—suggests the harsher sense of passing condemnatory judgment on others. "Judge" in English can sound neutral (like evaluating evidence), but Jesus is warning against a condemning posture toward others.

**"Performer" (v. 5)**: Greek ὑποκριτής means an actor on a stage. The singular vocative here addresses someone whose correction of others is theatrical performance rather than genuine care. This connects to the same vocabulary in chapter 6.

**"Beam" (v. 3-5)**: Greek δοκός refers to a construction timber or wooden beam—the hyperbole is intentionally absurd and humorous. A "log" works, but "beam" better captures the construction imagery.

**"How narrow" (v. 14)**: The text reads ὅτι, which most translations render "because" (continuing the reason from v. 13). However, ὅτι can also introduce an exclamation ("how!"), and this reading better fits the rhetorical force—the narrowness itself is the point, not an explanation of why to enter.

**"Constricted" (v. 14)**: Greek τεθλιμμένη is the perfect participle of θλίβω, "to press, afflict"—the same root as θλῖψις (tribulation). The road is not merely "narrow" (στενή describes the gate) but pressed-in, squeezed. This hints that the way to life involves pressure and difficulty.

**"Ravenous" (v. 15)**: Greek ἅρπαγες means seizing, plundering—wolves that grab and tear prey. "Ravenous" captures both the aggression and the predatory intent.

**"Workers of lawlessness" (v. 23)**: Greek οἱ ἐργαζόμενοι τὴν ἀνομίαν echoes Psalm 6:8 (LXX). The phrase suggests not occasional sin but a pattern of activity—those whose work is lawlessness. "Lawlessness" (ἀνομία) means living without regard for God's Torah, not just generic wrongdoing.

**"Rivers rose" (vv. 25, 27)**: Greek ποταμοί literally means "rivers," but in the Palestinian context of flash floods in wadis, the image is of seasonal torrents swelling and rushing. "Rivers rose" captures this better than simply "floods came."

verses.text: When he came down from the mountain, large crowds followed him.
And look—a man with a skin disease approached and bowed down before him, saying, "Lord, if you are willing, you are able to make me clean."
Reaching out his hand, he touched him, saying, "I am willing. Be cleansed." And immediately his skin disease was cleansed.
And Jesus says to him, "See that you tell no one. But go, show yourself to the priest and offer the gift that Moses commanded, as evidence to them."
When he entered Capernaum, a centurion approached him, pleading with him
and saying, "Lord, my servant lies paralyzed at home, suffering terrible torment."
And he says to him, "Am I to come and heal him?"
The centurion answered, "Lord, I am not worthy for you to come under my roof. But only speak the word, and my servant will be healed.
For I too am a man under authority, with soldiers under me, and I say to this one, 'Go,' and he goes, and to another, 'Come,' and he comes, and to my slave, 'Do this,' and he does it."
When Jesus heard this, he marveled and said to those following, "Truly I tell you, in no one in Israel have I found such faith.
I tell you that many will come from the east and the west and will recline at table with Abraham and Isaac and Jacob in the kingdom of the heavens,
but the heirs of the kingdom will be thrown out into the outer darkness. There will be weeping and grinding of teeth."
And Jesus said to the centurion, "Go. Let it be done for you as you have believed." And the servant was healed in that hour.
When Jesus came into Peter's house, he saw his mother-in-law lying sick with fever.
He touched her hand, and the fever released her. She got up and began serving him.
When evening came, they brought to him many who were demonized, and he drove out the spirits with a word and healed all who were afflicted,
so that what was spoken through the prophet Isaiah might be fulfilled: "He himself took our weaknesses and bore our diseases."
When Jesus saw the crowds around him, he gave orders to depart for the other side.
A scribe approached and said to him, "Teacher, I will follow you wherever you go."
Jesus says to him, "Foxes have dens, and the birds of the sky have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay his head."
Another of the disciples said to him, "Lord, permit me first to go and bury my father."
But Jesus says to him, "Follow me, and let the dead bury their own dead."
When he got into the boat, his disciples followed him.
And suddenly a great upheaval arose on the sea, so that the boat was being swamped by the waves—but he was sleeping.
They came and woke him, saying, "Lord, save us! We are perishing!"
He says to them, "Why are you afraid, you of little faith?" Then he rose and rebuked the winds and the sea, and there was a great calm.
The men marveled, saying, "What sort of man is this, that even the winds and the sea obey him?"
When he came to the other side, to the region of the Gadarenes, two demonized men met him, coming out of the tombs—so extremely dangerous that no one was able to pass by that road.
And suddenly they cried out, "What do you want with us, Son of God? Have you come here to torment us before the appointed time?"
Now some distance from them a large herd of pigs was feeding.
The demons begged him, "If you cast us out, send us into the herd of pigs."
And he said to them, "Go." They came out and went into the pigs, and suddenly the whole herd rushed down the steep bank into the sea and died in the waters.
The herdsmen fled, and going into the city, they reported everything—including what had happened to the demonized men.
And the whole city came out to meet Jesus, and when they saw him, they begged him to leave their region.

chapters.notes:
**"Am I to come and heal him?" (v. 7)**: The Greek ἐγὼ ἐλθὼν θεραπεύσω αὐτόν is typically translated as a statement ("I will come and heal him"), but the emphatic ἐγώ ("I myself") and the cultural context—a Jewish teacher entering a Gentile's home would cause ritual impurity—suggests this may be a question expressing hesitation or testing the centurion's understanding. The centurion's response (v. 8) makes better sense as answering such a question: "You don't need to come; just speak the word."

**"Heirs of the kingdom" (v. 12)**: The Greek υἱοὶ τῆς βασιλείας literally means "sons of the kingdom"—a Semitic idiom for those who belong to or are entitled to inherit something. "Heirs" captures this sense more naturally in English than the literal "sons."

**"Upheaval" (v. 24)**: Matthew uses σεισμός, the word for earthquake (from which "seismic" derives), rather than the typical storm vocabulary. This unusual word choice may evoke apocalyptic imagery or emphasize the cosmic scale of the disturbance. "Upheaval" preserves this distinctiveness better than "storm."

**"Swamped" (v. 24)**: The Greek καλύπτεσθαι means "being covered" or "being hidden"—the waves were overwhelming the boat. "Swamped" conveys both the water covering the boat and the sense of being overwhelmed.

**"What do you want with us?" (v. 29)**: The Greek τί ἡμῖν καὶ σοί is literally "What to us and to you?"—a Hebrew/Aramaic idiom expressing distance or conflict between parties. It appears throughout the Hebrew Bible (e.g., Judges 11:12; 2 Samuel 16:10) and conveys "What business do we have with each other?" or "Leave us alone!"

**"Before the appointed time" (v. 29)**: The phrase πρὸ καιροῦ indicates the demons recognize a scheduled time for their judgment—revealing their theological awareness that eschatological punishment awaits them.

verses.text: And getting into a boat, he crossed over and came to his own city.
And look, they were bringing to him a paralyzed man lying on a mat. And Jesus, seeing their faith, said to the paralyzed man, "Take courage, child—your sins are forgiven."
And look, some of the scribes said among themselves, "This man blasphemes."
And Jesus, knowing their thoughts, said, "Why do you think evil in your hearts?
For which is easier—to say, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say, 'Rise and walk'?
But so that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins"—then he says to the paralyzed man, "Rise, pick up your mat, and go to your home."
And he rose and went away to his home.
And when the crowds saw this, they were awestruck and glorified God, who had given such authority to human beings.
And as Jesus was passing on from there, he saw a man sitting at the tax booth, called Matthew, and says to him, "Follow me." And getting up, he followed him.
And it happened that as he was reclining at table in the house, look, many tax collectors and sinners came and were reclining at table with Jesus and his disciples.
And seeing this, the Pharisees said to his disciples, "Why does your teacher eat with tax collectors and sinners?"
But hearing this, he said, "The healthy have no need of a physician—but the sick do.
Go and learn what this means: 'I desire mercy, not sacrifice.' For I did not come to call the righteous, but sinners."
Then the disciples of John come to him, saying, "Why do we and the Pharisees fast often, but your disciples do not fast?"
And Jesus said to them, "Can the wedding guests mourn while the bridegroom is with them? But days will come when the bridegroom is taken from them, and then they will fast.
And no one puts a patch of unshrunk cloth on an old garment, for the patch pulls away from the garment, and a worse tear results.
Nor do they put new wine into old wineskins. Otherwise, the skins burst, the wine spills out, and the skins are ruined. Rather, they put new wine into fresh wineskins, and both are preserved."
While he was saying these things to them, look, an official came and was bowing before him, saying, "My daughter has just now died. But come and lay your hand on her, and she will live."
And Jesus rose and followed him, along with his disciples.
And look, a woman who had been suffering from bleeding for twelve years came up behind him and touched the fringe of his garment.
For she was saying to herself, "If I only touch his garment, I will be healed."
But Jesus turned and saw her and said, "Take courage, daughter—your faith has healed you." And the woman was healed from that hour.
And when Jesus came to the official's house and saw the flute players and the crowd in uproar,
he said, "Go away, for the girl has not died but is sleeping." And they laughed at him.
But when the crowd had been put out, he went in and took her by the hand, and the girl rose.
And the news of this went out into all that region.
And as Jesus was passing on from there, two blind men followed him, crying out and saying, "Have mercy on us, Son of David!"
And when he came into the house, the blind men came to him, and Jesus says to them, "Do you believe that I am able to do this?" They say to him, "Yes, Lord."
Then he touched their eyes, saying, "According to your faith, let it be done to you."
And their eyes were opened. And Jesus sternly warned them, saying, "See that no one knows about this."
But they went out and spread the news about him throughout all that region.
As they were going out, look, they brought to him a mute man who was demon-possessed.
And when the demon had been cast out, the mute man spoke. And the crowds marveled, saying, "Never has anything like this been seen in Israel!"
But the Pharisees were saying, "By the ruler of the demons he casts out demons."
And Jesus was traveling through all the cities and villages, teaching in their synagogues and proclaiming the good news of the kingdom, and healing every disease and every illness.
And seeing the crowds, he was moved with compassion for them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd.
Then he says to his disciples, "The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few.
Therefore, plead with the lord of the harvest to send out workers into his harvest."

chapters.notes:
**"Wedding guests" (v. 15)**: The Greek οἱ υἱοὶ τοῦ νυμφῶνος literally means "the sons of the bridal chamber," an Aramaic idiom (בני חופה) for those attending a wedding celebration. Note that Matthew uses "mourn" (πενθεῖν) rather than "fast," linking fasting to mourning and making Jesus's point more vivid: mourning at a wedding is absurd.

**"Fringe" (v. 20)**: The Greek κράσπεδον refers to the ritual tassels (tzitzit) commanded in Numbers 15:38-39. A first-century Jewish audience would recognize this as a mark of Torah observance—the woman reaches for Jesus's visible sign of covenant faithfulness.

**"Healed" (vv. 21-22)**: The Greek σῴζω means both "save" and "heal." The woman thinks "I will be healed/saved" (σωθήσομαι), and Jesus declares "your faith has healed/saved you" (σέσωκέν σε). The ambiguity is intentional—physical healing and spiritual salvation are intertwined.

**"To human beings" (v. 8)**: The plural τοῖς ἀνθρώποις is surprising—the crowds glorify God for giving such authority not just to Jesus but "to humans." This may reflect Matthew's interest in how Jesus's authority extends to his community.

**"Harassed and helpless" (v. 36)**: The Greek ἐσκυλμένοι καὶ ἐρριμμένοι conveys being worn down and cast aside—like sheep scattered by predators or neglect. The imagery echoes prophetic critiques of Israel's failed shepherds (Ezekiel 34; Numbers 27:17).

**"Send out" (v. 38)**: The Greek ἐκβάλῃ is the same verb used for casting out demons—it suggests urgency and force. God must thrust workers into the harvest, not merely dispatch them.

**"Sternly warned" (v. 30)**: The Greek ἐνεβριμήθη carries strong emotional force, suggesting indignation or intensity. Jesus's secrecy commands throughout Matthew are emphatic, not casual requests.

verses.text: And having summoned his twelve disciples, he gave them authority over unclean spirits, to cast them out and to heal every disease and every ailment.
Now the names of the twelve apostles are these: first, Simon who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother; James the son of Zebedee and John his brother;
Philip and Bartholomew; Thomas and Matthew the tax collector; James the son of Alphaeus and Thaddaeus;
Simon the Zealot, and Judas Iscariot—the one who handed him over.
These twelve Jesus sent out, instructing them: "Do not go on any road leading to the Gentiles, and do not enter any town of the Samaritans.
Go rather to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.
And as you go, proclaim: 'The kingdom of the heavens has drawn near.'
Heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse those with skin diseases, cast out demons. Freely you received; freely give.
"Do not acquire gold or silver or copper for your money-belts,
nor a traveler's bag for the road, nor two tunics, nor sandals, nor a staff—for the worker is worthy of his food.
Whatever town or village you enter, find out who in it is worthy, and stay there until you leave.
As you enter the house, greet it.
And if the house is worthy, let your peace come upon it; but if it is not worthy, let your peace return to you.
And whoever does not receive you or listen to your words—as you leave that house or that town, shake off the dust from your feet.
Truly I tell you, it will be more bearable for the land of Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment than for that town.
"Look—I am sending you out as sheep in the midst of wolves. So become shrewd as serpents and innocent as doves.
But beware of people, for they will hand you over to councils and flog you in their synagogues.
And you will be brought before governors and kings on account of me, as a witness to them and to the nations.
But when they hand you over, do not be anxious about how to speak or what to say, for what you are to say will be given to you in that hour.
For it is not you who are speaking, but the Spirit of your Father speaking through you.
"Brother will hand over brother to death, and a father his child, and children will rise up against parents and have them put to death.
And you will be hated by all because of my name. But the one who endures to the end—this one will be saved.
When they persecute you in one town, flee to the next. For truly I tell you, you will not finish going through the towns of Israel before the Son of Man comes.
"A disciple is not above the teacher, nor a slave above his master.
It is enough for the disciple to become like his teacher, and the slave like his master. If they have called the master of the house Beelzebul, how much more the members of his household!
"So do not fear them. For nothing is concealed that will not be revealed, and nothing hidden that will not be made known.
What I tell you in the darkness, speak in the light; and what you hear whispered in your ear, proclaim from the housetops.
And do not fear those who kill the body but cannot kill the soul. Rather, fear the one who is able to destroy both soul and body in Gehenna.
"Are not two sparrows sold for a single assarion? Yet not one of them will fall to the ground apart from your Father.
And even the hairs of your head are all numbered.
So do not fear—you are worth more than many sparrows.
"Everyone therefore who acknowledges me before others, I also will acknowledge before my Father who is in the heavens.
But whoever denies me before others, I also will deny before my Father who is in the heavens.
"Do not think that I came to bring peace upon the earth. I did not come to bring peace, but a sword.
For I came to set a man against his father, and a daughter against her mother, and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.
And a person's enemies will be the members of his own household.
"Whoever loves father or mother more than me is not worthy of me, and whoever loves son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.
And whoever does not take up his cross and follow after me is not worthy of me.
Whoever finds his life will lose it, and whoever loses his life for my sake will find it.
"Whoever receives you receives me, and whoever receives me receives the one who sent me.
Whoever receives a prophet because he is a prophet will receive a prophet's reward, and whoever receives a righteous person because he is righteous will receive a righteous person's reward.
And whoever gives even a cup of cold water to one of these little ones because he is a disciple—truly I tell you, that person will certainly not lose their reward."

chapters.notes:
**"Simon the Zealot" (v. 4)**: The Greek Καναναῖος is not "Canaanite" but a transliteration of the Aramaic word for "zealot" (קנאי). This describes either Simon's temperament or his association with the Zealot movement. "Zealot" captures this better than the misleading "Cananaean."

**"Handed him over" (v. 4)**: The verb παραδίδωμι means "hand over, deliver up." While often translated "betray," the Greek word itself is neutral—the same verb describes what councils will do to the disciples (v. 17, 19, 21). "Handed over" preserves this connection and lets the context convey the treachery.

**"Has drawn near" (v. 7)**: The perfect tense ἤγγικεν indicates completed action with ongoing results—the kingdom has come near and remains near. This is stronger than simply "is coming."

**"Money-belts" (v. 9)**: The ζώνη was the belt or sash where travelers kept coins. "Money-belts" makes explicit what would have been obvious to ancient readers.

**"Let your peace come upon it... return to you" (v. 13)**: This reflects the Semitic understanding of שָׁלוֹם (shalom) as something substantial that can rest on a household or return to its source—not merely a verbal greeting.

**"Beelzebul" (v. 25)**: There is deliberate wordplay here: Jesus is called the οἰκοδεσπότης ("master of the house"), and Beelzebul likely means "lord of the house" (Baal-zebul) in Aramaic. The contrast between the true master of the house and this demonic title is intentional. The disciples are the οἰκιακοί ("household members").

**"Gehenna" (v. 28)**: Retained rather than "hell" because Gehenna refers specifically to the Valley of Hinnom outside Jerusalem, a place associated with judgment. It carries different connotations than the generic English "hell."

**"Assarion" (v. 29)**: This was a Roman copper coin worth 1/16 of a denarius—a trivial amount. Retaining the term emphasizes how cheap sparrows were while avoiding awkward modern currency equivalents.

**"Acknowledges me" (v. 32)**: The unusual Greek construction ὁμολογήσει ἐν ἐμοί ("confess in me") reflects a Semitic idiom meaning to acknowledge loyalty or solidarity with someone. This is more than mere verbal confession—it involves public identification with Jesus.

**"Life/soul" (v. 39)**: The Greek ψυχή can mean either "life" or "soul." In this paradoxical saying, "life" captures the point better: the one who grasps after their life (seeking to preserve it) will lose it, while the one who loses their life for Jesus's sake will find it.

verses.text: And it happened that when Jesus finished giving instructions to his twelve disciples, he went on from there to teach and proclaim in their towns.
Now John, having heard in prison about the works of the Messiah, sent word through his disciples
and asked him, "Are you the Coming One, or should we expect someone else?"
Jesus answered them, "Go and report to John what you are hearing and seeing:
The blind are receiving their sight and the lame are walking, lepers are being cleansed and the deaf are hearing, the dead are being raised and the poor are receiving good news.
And blessed is anyone who does not stumble because of me."
As they were leaving, Jesus began to speak to the crowds about John: "What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed swaying in the wind?
Then what did you go out to see? A man dressed in soft clothing? Look, those who wear soft clothes are in the palaces of kings.
Then what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and more than a prophet.
This is the one about whom it is written: 'Look, I am sending my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way before you.'
Truly I tell you, among those born of women no one greater than John the Baptizer has arisen. Yet the least in the kingdom of the heavens is greater than he.
From the days of John the Baptizer until now, the kingdom of the heavens is being forcefully entered, and the forceful are seizing it.
For all the Prophets and the Law prophesied until John.
And if you are willing to accept it, he is Elijah who is about to come.
Let the one who has ears, hear.
"But to what shall I compare this generation? It is like children sitting in the marketplaces who call out to the others,
saying, 'We played the flute for you and you did not dance; we sang a dirge and you did not beat your chests.'
For John came neither eating nor drinking, and they say, 'He has a demon.'
The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and they say, 'Look, a glutton and a drunk, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!' Yet wisdom is vindicated by her deeds."
Then he began to denounce the towns in which most of his mighty works had been done, because they did not repent:
"Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in sackcloth and ashes.
But I tell you, it will be more bearable for Tyre and Sidon on the day of judgment than for you.
And you, Capernaum—will you be exalted to heaven? You will descend to Hades. For if the mighty works done in you had been done in Sodom, it would have remained until this day.
But I tell you that it will be more bearable for the land of Sodom on the day of judgment than for you."
At that time Jesus declared, "I praise you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and intelligent and revealed them to infants.
Yes, Father, for this was your good pleasure."

"All things have been entrusted to me by my Father, and no one fully knows the Son except the Father, nor does anyone fully know the Father except the Son—and anyone to whom the Son chooses to reveal him."
"Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest.
Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.
For my yoke is easy and my burden is light."

chapters.notes:
**"The Coming One" (v. 3)**: ὁ ἐρχόμενος functions as a messianic title—"the one who is coming" in a pregnant sense, referring to the expected deliverer. John's question is not "Are you coming?" but "Are you *the* Coming One?"—that is, the awaited figure.

**"Stumble because of me" (v. 6)**: σκανδαλισθῇ refers to being caused to fall or trip—here metaphorically, to find Jesus an obstacle to faith, to take offense at him. The image is of a stumbling block.

**"Kingdom of the heavens" (vv. 11, 12)**: Matthew consistently uses the plural τῶν οὐρανῶν, reflecting the Hebrew שָׁמַיִם (shamayim), which is grammatically plural. I preserve this Matthean distinctive.

**"Is being forcefully entered... the forceful are seizing it" (v. 12)**: This notoriously difficult verse hinges on whether βιάζεται is passive ("suffers violence") or middle ("advances forcefully"). Either reading, combined with "the forceful seize it" (ἁρπάζουσιν), could be positive (eager seekers pressing in) or negative (violent opposition). My rendering preserves the ambiguity while leaning toward the middle voice—the kingdom is being entered with force by those who urgently press into it.

**"Beat your chests" (v. 17)**: ἐκόψασθε (from κόπτω) means to strike or beat oneself as a sign of mourning—more specific than simply "mourn."

**"Fully knows" (v. 27)**: ἐπιγινώσκει is the intensive form of γινώσκω, indicating complete, intimate knowledge—not mere acquaintance but thorough recognition.

**"Infants" (v. 25)**: νηπίοις specifically means infants or very young children, emphasizing the stark contrast with "the wise and intelligent" (σοφῶν καὶ συνετῶν). "Little children" softens this contrast.

**"Lowly in heart" (v. 29)**: ταπεινός means low, humble, of low status—not merely "humble" in the modern sense of modest self-assessment, but genuinely lowly, unassuming in disposition.

verses.text: At that time Jesus walked through the grain fields on the Sabbath. His disciples grew hungry and began to pluck heads of grain and eat them.
But the Pharisees, seeing this, said to him, "Look! Your disciples are doing what is not permitted on the Sabbath."
He said to them, "Have you not read what David did when he and those with him were hungry—
how he entered the house of God and they ate the bread of the Presence, which was not permitted for him to eat, nor for those with him, but only for the priests?
Or have you not read in the Law that on the Sabbath the priests in the temple profane the Sabbath and yet are guiltless?
But I tell you: something greater than the temple is here.
If you had understood what this means—'I desire mercy and not sacrifice'—you would not have condemned the innocent.
For the Son of Man is lord of the Sabbath."
Moving on from there, he went into their synagogue.
And there was a man with a withered hand. They questioned him, asking, "Is it permitted to heal on the Sabbath?"—so that they might bring charges against him.
He said to them, "What person among you who has one sheep, if it falls into a pit on the Sabbath, will not take hold of it and lift it out?
How much more valuable, then, is a human being than a sheep! So it is permitted to do good on the Sabbath."
Then he said to the man, "Stretch out your hand." He stretched it out, and it was restored to full health like the other.
But the Pharisees went out and plotted against him, how they might destroy him.
Jesus, knowing this, withdrew from there. Many followed him, and he healed them all,
and he warned them not to make him known—
so that what was spoken through Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled:
"Look, my servant whom I have chosen, my beloved in whom my soul delights. I will put my Spirit upon him, and he will proclaim justice to the nations.
He will not quarrel nor cry out, nor will anyone hear his voice in the streets.
A bruised reed he will not break, and a smoldering wick he will not extinguish, until he brings justice to victory.
And in his name the nations will hope."
Then they brought to him a demon-possessed man who was blind and mute, and he healed him so that the mute man both spoke and saw.
All the crowds were astonished and kept saying, "This couldn't be the Son of David, could it?"
But when the Pharisees heard this, they said, "This man does not cast out demons except by Beelzebul, the ruler of demons."
Knowing their thoughts, he said to them, "Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to ruin, and every city or household divided against itself will not stand.
If Satan casts out Satan, he is divided against himself—how then will his kingdom stand?
And if I cast out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your own sons cast them out? For this reason, they will be your judges.
But if I cast out demons by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God has arrived upon you.
Or how can anyone enter the strong man's house and plunder his possessions unless he first binds the strong man? Then he can plunder his house.
"The one who is not with me is against me, and the one who does not gather with me scatters.
For this reason I tell you: every sin and blasphemy will be forgiven people, but blasphemy against the Spirit will not be forgiven.
Whoever speaks a word against the Son of Man, it will be forgiven him. But whoever speaks against the Holy Spirit, it will not be forgiven him—neither in this age nor in the age to come.
"Either make the tree good and its fruit good, or make the tree rotten and its fruit rotten—for the tree is known by its fruit.
Brood of vipers! How can you speak good things when you are evil? For from the overflow of the heart the mouth speaks.
The good person brings forth good things from a good treasury, and the evil person brings forth evil things from an evil treasury.
But I tell you that for every worthless word that people speak, they will render an account on the day of judgment.
For by your words you will be vindicated, and by your words you will be condemned."
Then some of the scribes and Pharisees answered him, saying, "Teacher, we want to see a sign from you."
But he answered them, "An evil and unfaithful generation demands a sign, and no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah the prophet.
For just as Jonah was in the belly of the great sea creature three days and three nights, so the Son of Man will be in the heart of the earth three days and three nights.
The men of Nineveh will rise up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, because they repented at the proclamation of Jonah—and look, something greater than Jonah is here.

The queen of the South will rise up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, because she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon—and look, something greater than Solomon is here.
"When an unclean spirit goes out of a person, it wanders through waterless places seeking rest and finds none.
Then it says, 'I will return to my house from which I came.' And arriving, it finds it unoccupied, swept clean, and put in order.

Then it goes and brings along with itself seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they enter and settle there. And the final condition of that person becomes worse than the first. So it will be also with this evil generation."
While he was still speaking to the crowds, his mother and brothers stood outside, wanting to speak with him.
Someone said to him, "Look, your mother and your brothers are standing outside, wanting to speak with you."
But he answered the one who told him, "Who is my mother, and who are my brothers?"
And stretching out his hand toward his disciples, he said, "Look—my mother and my brothers!
For whoever does the will of my Father who is in the heavens—that person is my brother and sister and mother."

chapters.notes:
**"Something greater" (vv. 6, 41, 42)**: The Greek μεῖζον and πλεῖον are neuter, not masculine. While Jesus is clearly the referent, the neuter form broadens the claim—it is not merely that a greater person is here, but that a greater reality, a greater order of things, has arrived. This preserves an important ambiguity in the original.

**"Bread of the Presence" (v. 4)**: The Greek ἄρτους τῆς προθέσεως translates the Hebrew לֶחֶם הַפָּנִים, literally "bread of the face/presence." This was the bread set before YHWH's presence in the tabernacle/temple.

**"Arrived upon you" (v. 28)**: The verb ἔφθασεν carries a sense of arrival, of having reached or come upon. The kingdom has not merely "come near" but has arrived—an important distinction for the eschatological claim being made.

**"Unfaithful generation" (v. 39)**: The Greek μοιχαλίς means "adulterous," but this draws on the prophetic tradition where Israel's unfaithfulness to YHWH is depicted as marital infidelity (Hosea, Jeremiah, Ezekiel). "Unfaithful" captures this covenantal dimension better than the narrowly sexual connotation of "adulterous" in modern English.

**"Great sea creature" (v. 40)**: The Greek κῆτος refers to a large sea creature or sea monster, not specifically a whale. The LXX of Jonah 2:1 uses the same term.

**"Worthless word" (v. 36)**: The Greek ἀργόν (from ἀ-εργος, "not working") means idle, useless, or ineffective—words that accomplish nothing good. "Careless" in some translations suggests mere thoughtlessness, but the Greek emphasizes the word's lack of productive value.

**"This couldn't be the Son of David, could it?" (v. 23)**: The particle μήτι in a question expects a negative answer but with an undertone of hope or wonder. The crowd is tentatively entertaining the possibility while not quite daring to affirm it.

**"Brood of vipers" (v. 34)**: γεννήματα ἐχιδνῶν—literally "offspring of vipers." This echoes John the Baptist's language (Matt 3:7) and implies they have inherited a poisonous nature from their spiritual parentage.

**"Treasury" (v. 35)**: The Greek θησαυρός means a storehouse or treasury—a place where valuables are accumulated. The heart is portrayed as a repository from which one draws forth what has been stored there.

verses.text: On that day Jesus went out of the house and sat beside the sea.
And such large crowds gathered around him that he got into a boat and sat down, while the whole crowd stood on the shore.
And he spoke many things to them in parables, saying: "Look! A sower went out to sow.
And as he sowed, some seeds fell along the path, and the birds came and devoured them.
Other seeds fell on rocky ground where they did not have much soil, and they sprang up immediately because they had no depth of soil.
But when the sun rose they were scorched, and because they had no root they withered.
Other seeds fell among the thorns, and the thorns grew up and choked them.
But other seeds fell on the good soil and kept yielding fruit—some a hundredfold, some sixty, some thirty.
The one who has ears, let him hear."
And the disciples came and said to him, "Why do you speak to them in parables?"
He answered them, "Because to you it has been given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of the heavens, but to them it has not been given.
For whoever has, more will be given to him and he will have abundance; but whoever does not have, even what he has will be taken from him.
This is why I speak to them in parables: because seeing they do not see, and hearing they do not hear, nor do they understand.
And in them the prophecy of Isaiah is being fulfilled that says: 'You will hear and hear but never understand, and you will look and look but never perceive.

For the heart of this people has grown dull, and with their ears they hear with difficulty, and they have shut their eyes— lest they see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart and turn back, and I would heal them.'
But blessed are your eyes because they see, and your ears because they hear.
For truly I tell you, many prophets and righteous ones longed to see what you see and did not see it, and to hear what you hear and did not hear it.
"So you, hear the parable of the sower.
When anyone hears the word of the kingdom and does not understand it, the evil one comes and snatches away what was sown in his heart. This is what was sown along the path.
What was sown on rocky ground—this is the one who hears the word and immediately receives it with joy,
but has no root in himself and lasts only a short time. When affliction or persecution arises because of the word, immediately he falls away.
What was sown among thorns—this is the one who hears the word, but the anxiety of this age and the seduction of wealth choke the word, and it becomes fruitless.
But what was sown on the good soil—this is the one who hears the word and understands it, who indeed bears fruit and produces: one a hundredfold, another sixty, another thirty."
He set another parable before them, saying: "The kingdom of the heavens may be compared to a man who sowed good seed in his field.
But while people were sleeping, his enemy came and sowed darnel among the wheat and went away.
When the plants sprouted and produced grain, then the darnel also appeared.
The servants of the master of the house came and said to him, 'Master, did you not sow good seed in your field? Where then did the darnel come from?'
He said to them, 'An enemy has done this.' The servants said to him, 'Then do you want us to go and gather it?'
But he said, 'No, lest in gathering the darnel you uproot the wheat along with it.
Let both grow together until the harvest, and at harvest time I will tell the reapers: First gather the darnel and bind it in bundles to burn it, but gather the wheat into my barn.'"
He set another parable before them, saying: "The kingdom of the heavens is like a mustard seed that a man took and sowed in his field.
It is the smallest of all the seeds, but when it has grown it is larger than the garden plants and becomes a tree, so that the birds of the sky come and nest in its branches."
He told them another parable: "The kingdom of the heavens is like leaven that a woman took and hid in three measures of flour until the whole batch was leavened."
All these things Jesus spoke to the crowds in parables, and without a parable he said nothing to them,
so that what was spoken through the prophet might be fulfilled: "I will open my mouth in parables; I will pour forth things hidden since the foundation."
Then he left the crowds and went into the house. And his disciples came to him, saying, "Explain to us the parable of the darnel of the field."
He answered: "The one who sows the good seed is the Son of Man.
The field is the world. The good seed—these are the sons of the kingdom. The darnel are the sons of the evil one,
and the enemy who sowed them is the devil. The harvest is the completion of the age, and the reapers are angels.
Just as the darnel is gathered and burned with fire, so it will be at the completion of the age.
The Son of Man will send his angels, and they will gather out of his kingdom all causes of stumbling and those who practice lawlessness,
and they will throw them into the furnace of fire. There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Then the righteous will shine forth like the sun in the kingdom of their Father. The one who has ears, let him hear.
"The kingdom of the heavens is like treasure hidden in a field that a man found and hid again. And in his joy he goes and sells everything he has and buys that field.
"Again, the kingdom of the heavens is like a merchant seeking fine pearls.
Finding one pearl of great value, he went and sold everything he had and bought it.
"Again, the kingdom of the heavens is like a dragnet cast into the sea that gathered fish of every kind.
When it was full, they hauled it up onto the shore, and sitting down they sorted the good into containers but threw out the worthless.
So it will be at the completion of the age. The angels will go out and separate the wicked from among the righteous
and throw them into the furnace of fire. There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth."
"Have you understood all these things?" They said to him, "Yes."
And he said to them, "Therefore every scribe who has been trained for the kingdom of the heavens is like a master of a household who brings out of his storeroom things new and old."
And when Jesus had finished these parables, he departed from there.
Coming to his hometown, he taught them in their synagogue, so that they were astonished and said, "Where did this man get this wisdom and these powers?
Is this not the craftsman's son? Is not his mother called Mary, and his brothers James and Joseph and Simon and Judas?
And are not all his sisters here with us? Where then did he get all these things?"
And they took offense at him. But Jesus said to them, "A prophet is not without honor except in his hometown and in his own house."
And he did not do many mighty works there because of their unbelief.

chapters.notes:
**"Darnel" (vv. 25-40)**: The Greek ζιζάνια refers specifically to *Lolium temulentum*, a weed virtually indistinguishable from wheat until the heads appear. The traditional "tares" is archaic and meaningless to modern readers; "weeds" is too generic and misses the parable's point about deceptive resemblance. "Darnel" preserves the specific agricultural reality that makes the parable work.

**"Kingdom of the heavens"**: Matthew consistently uses βασιλεία τῶν οὐρανῶν (plural "heavens") where other gospels say "kingdom of God"—reflecting Jewish circumlocution avoiding the divine name. I preserve the plural to maintain Matthew's distinctive voice.

**"Completion of the age" (vv. 39, 40, 49)**: συντέλεια αἰῶνος is better than "end of the world" or "end of the age." The Greek implies consummation or bringing to completion, not mere termination, and αἰών refers to an age or epoch, not the physical world (κόσμος).

**"Seduction of wealth" (v. 22)**: ἀπάτη τοῦ πλούτου suggests wealth's deceptive allure—it promises what it cannot deliver. "Deceitfulness" is accurate but passive; "seduction" captures the active, enticing quality of the deception.

**"Kept yielding" (v. 8)**: The imperfect ἐδίδου suggests ongoing, continuous production rather than a single harvest event.
