**"Pour forth" (v. 35)**: ἐρεύξομαι literally means "belch forth" or "utter with full voice"—a vivid word for prophetic proclamation. "Pour forth" captures the abundance implied without the unfortunate connotations of "belch" in English.

**"Lasts only a short time" (v. 21)**: πρόσκαιρος means "lasting for a season, temporary." "He is temporary" sounds odd in English; this rendering clarifies the meaning while preserving the sense that the person's commitment has no endurance.

**"Craftsman's son" (v. 55)**: τέκτων encompasses woodworking, construction, and general skilled craftsmanship. "Carpenter" is traditional but potentially too narrow; "craftsman" better reflects the range of work such a tradesman would perform.

**"Causes of stumbling" (v. 41)**: σκάνδαλα originally referred to the trigger of a trap—something that causes someone to fall. The English "scandals" has drifted toward mere embarrassment or impropriety.

verses.text: At that time, Herod the tetrarch heard the report about Jesus,
and he said to his servants, "This is John the Baptizer—he has been raised from the dead, and that is why these powers are at work in him."
For Herod had arrested John, bound him, and put him away in prison on account of Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip.
John had been telling him, "It is not lawful for you to have her."
And though Herod wanted to kill him, he feared the crowd, because they regarded him as a prophet.
But when Herod's birthday celebration came, the daughter of Herodias danced before the guests and pleased Herod,
so that he promised with an oath to give her whatever she might ask.
Having been coached by her mother, she said, "Give me here on a platter the head of John the Baptizer."
The king was grieved, but because of his oaths and his dinner guests, he commanded it to be given.
He sent and had John beheaded in the prison.
His head was brought on a platter and given to the girl, and she carried it to her mother.
John's disciples came, took the body, and buried him. Then they went and reported it to Jesus.
When Jesus heard this, he withdrew from there by boat to a desolate place by himself. But the crowds heard of it and followed him on foot from the towns.
When he came ashore, he saw a great crowd, and his gut was wrenched with compassion for them, and he healed their sick.

When evening came, the disciples approached him, saying, "This place is desolate and the hour has already grown late. Send the crowds away so they can go into the villages and buy food for themselves."
But Jesus said to them, "They have no need to go away. You give them something to eat."
They said to him, "We have nothing here except five loaves and two fish."
He said, "Bring them here to me."

After ordering the crowds to recline on the grass, he took the five loaves and the two fish, and looking up to heaven, he said the blessing. Then, breaking the loaves, he gave them to the disciples, and the disciples gave them to the crowds.
Everyone ate and was satisfied, and they gathered up what remained of the broken pieces—twelve baskets full.
Those who had eaten were about five thousand men, not counting women and children.
Immediately he compelled the disciples to get into the boat and go ahead of him to the other side, while he dismissed the crowds.
After sending the crowds away, he went up on the mountain by himself to pray. When evening came, he was there alone.
The boat was already many stadia from land, being battered by the waves, for the wind was against them.
In the fourth watch of the night, he came to them, walking on the sea.
When the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were terrified, saying, "It is a ghost!" and they cried out in fear.
But immediately Jesus spoke to them, saying, "Take courage—I am—do not be afraid."
Peter answered him, "Lord, if it is you, command me to come to you on the water."
He said, "Come." And Peter stepped down from the boat and walked on the water and came toward Jesus.
But when he saw the wind, he was afraid, and beginning to sink, he cried out, "Lord, save me!"
Immediately Jesus stretched out his hand and took hold of him, saying to him, "You of little faith—why did you waver?"
When they got into the boat, the wind ceased.
And those in the boat bowed down before him, saying, "Truly you are God's Son."
When they had crossed over, they came to land at Gennesaret.
When the men of that place recognized him, they sent word throughout that whole surrounding region, and people brought to him all who were sick.
They kept begging him to let them only touch the tassel of his cloak—and as many as touched it were healed completely.

chapters.notes:
**"Tetrarch" (v. 1) / "king" (v. 9)**: Herod Antipas was technically a tetrarch (ruler of a quarter), not a king—a title Rome denied him. Matthew preserves this distinction in verse 1 but uses "king" (βασιλεύς) in verse 9, perhaps reflecting popular usage or the irony of his pretensions.

**"His gut was wrenched with compassion" (v. 14)**: The Greek ἐσπλαγχνίσθη derives from σπλάγχνα (intestines, inward parts). This is visceral, gut-level compassion—not mere sympathy but a physical response. Most translations flatten this to "had compassion," losing the bodily force.

**"I am" (v. 27)**: The Greek ἐγώ εἰμι can mean simply "It is I" (self-identification), but it also carries divine resonance from the LXX's rendering of God's self-revelation (Exodus 3:14). In a theophany-like scene where Jesus walks on water and calms the storm, the ambiguity seems deliberate. I preserve both senses with the bare "I am."

**"Waver" (v. 31)**: The Greek διστάζω comes from δίς (twice)—to be of two minds, to hesitate between two positions. "Doubt" in modern English suggests intellectual uncertainty; the Greek implies divided attention or split commitment. Peter wasn't questioning Jesus's identity—he was looking at both Jesus and the wind.

**"Tassel" (v. 36)**: The κράσπεδον is the tzitzit—the fringed tassels that observant Jewish men wore on their garments as commanded in Numbers 15:38-39. This detail shows Jesus wearing the visible markers of Jewish observance and connects to the woman with the hemorrhage (Matt 9:20).

**"Healed completely" (v. 36)**: The Greek διεσώθησαν (from διασῴζω) is intensive—saved through, brought safely through, thoroughly healed. The prefix διά- intensifies the basic verb σῴζω (save/heal).

verses.text: Then Pharisees and scribes from Jerusalem come to Jesus, saying,
"Why do your disciples violate the tradition of the elders? For they do not wash their hands when they eat bread."
But answering he said to them, "Why do you also violate the commandment of God for the sake of your tradition?
For God said, 'Honor your father and your mother,' and, 'The one who speaks evil of father or mother must surely die.'
But you say, 'Whoever says to father or mother, "Whatever you might have benefited from me is a gift to God"—
he certainly will not honor his father.' And so you have nullified the word of God for the sake of your tradition.
Performers! Isaiah prophesied rightly about you when he said:
'This people honors me with their lips, but their heart holds far from me.
In vain they worship me, teaching as doctrines the commandments of human beings.'"
And calling the crowd to him, he said to them, "Listen and understand:
It is not what enters the mouth that defiles a person, but what comes out of the mouth—this is what defiles a person."
Then the disciples came and said to him, "Do you know that the Pharisees were scandalized when they heard this saying?"
But answering he said, "Every plant that my heavenly Father did not plant will be uprooted.
Leave them alone. They are blind guides of the blind. And if a blind person guides a blind person, both will fall into a pit."
Then Peter answered and said to him, "Explain this parable to us."
And he said, "Are you also still without understanding?
Do you not grasp that everything entering the mouth passes into the stomach and is expelled into the latrine?
But the things that come out of the mouth come from the heart, and these defile the person.
For out of the heart come evil intentions, murders, adulteries, sexual immoralities, thefts, false testimonies, slanders.
These are what defile a person, but eating with unwashed hands does not defile a person."
And leaving from there, Jesus withdrew to the region of Tyre and Sidon.
And look—a Canaanite woman from that region came out and was crying out, saying, "Have mercy on me, Lord, Son of David! My daughter is severely tormented by a demon."
But he did not answer her a word. And his disciples came and kept urging him, saying, "Send her away, because she keeps crying out behind us."
But answering he said, "I was sent only to the lost sheep of the house of Israel."
But she came and knelt before him, saying, "Lord, help me!"
But answering he said, "It is not right to take the children's bread and throw it to the little dogs."
But she said, "Yes, Lord—yet even the little dogs eat from the crumbs that fall from their masters' table."
Then Jesus answered and said to her, "O woman, great is your faith! Let it be done for you as you wish." And her daughter was healed from that hour.
And moving on from there, Jesus came alongside the Sea of Galilee, and going up on the mountain, he sat down there.
And great crowds came to him, bringing with them the mute, blind, lame, maimed, and many others, and they laid them at his feet, and he healed them—
so that the crowd was amazed as they saw the mute speaking, the maimed restored, the lame walking, and the blind seeing. And they glorified the God of Israel.

Then Jesus called his disciples to him and said, "I have compassion on the crowd, because they have already remained with me three days and have nothing to eat. I am not willing to send them away hungry, lest they collapse on the way."
And the disciples said to him, "Where in this desolate place could we get enough loaves to satisfy such a large crowd?"
And Jesus said to them, "How many loaves do you have?" And they said, "Seven, and a few small fish."
And commanding the crowd to recline on the ground,
he took the seven loaves and the fish, and after giving thanks he broke them and kept giving them to the disciples, and the disciples to the crowds.
And they all ate and were satisfied, and they picked up the leftover fragments—seven large baskets full.
Now those who ate were four thousand men, besides women and children.
And after dismissing the crowds, he got into the boat and came to the region of Magadan.

chapters.notes:
**"Violate" (vv. 2, 3)**: The Greek παραβαίνω appears in both the Pharisees' accusation (v. 2) and Jesus's counter-question (v. 3). Preserving the same English word shows Jesus deliberately turning their language back on them—they accuse his disciples of violating tradition; he accuses them of violating God's commandment.

**"Performers" (v. 7)**: Greek ὑποκριταί—theatrical actors. Jesus's charge is not that they privately believe differently than they publicly act, but that their religion is a performance for an audience.

**"Nullified" (v. 6)**: Greek ἠκυρώσατε is legal/commercial terminology for voiding a contract or rendering something invalid. Their tradition doesn't just set aside God's word—it actively cancels it.

**"Defiles" (vv. 11, 18, 20)**: Greek κοινοῖ literally means "makes common" (as opposed to holy). In Jewish purity discourse, this refers to ritual contamination that excludes one from sacred participation. "Defile" captures the religious weight better than "make unclean."

**"Scandalized" (v. 12)**: Greek ἐσκανδαλίσθησαν—caused to stumble over an obstacle (σκάνδαλον). More than mere offense; it implies being tripped up in their faith or caused to fall away.

**"Little dogs" (vv. 26-27)**: Greek κυνάρια is a diminutive—not wild scavenging dogs (a common Jewish insult for Gentiles) but household pets. The woman brilliantly accepts Jesus's metaphor while noting that even household dogs receive something from the family table.

**"Large baskets" (v. 37)**: Greek σπυρίδας refers to large woven baskets, distinct from the κόφινοι ("small baskets") in the feeding of the five thousand (14:20). The distinction may carry symbolic significance—κόφινοι were characteristically Jewish traveling baskets, while σπυρίδες were more general.

**"The God of Israel" (v. 31)**: This unusual phrase (rather than simply "God") suggests the crowd includes Gentiles who recognize Israel's God through Jesus's healing works—fitting the geographic and narrative context following the Canaanite woman episode.

verses.text: The Pharisees and Sadducees approached, and testing him, they asked him to display a sign from heaven for them.
He answered them, "When evening comes, you say, 'Fair weather—for the sky is red.'
And in the morning, 'Stormy weather today—for the sky is red and threatening.' You know how to read the face of the sky, but you cannot read the signs of the times.
An evil and unfaithful generation demands a sign, yet no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah." And leaving them behind, he departed.
When the disciples crossed to the other side, they had forgotten to bring bread.
Jesus said to them, "Watch out—beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees."
They discussed this among themselves, saying, "It is because we did not bring bread."
But Jesus, knowing this, said, "Why are you discussing among yourselves, you of little faith, that you have no bread?
Do you still not understand? Do you not remember the five loaves for the five thousand, and how many baskets you collected?
Or the seven loaves for the four thousand, and how many large baskets you collected?
How can you not understand that I was not speaking to you about bread? Beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees."
Then they understood that he had not told them to beware of the leaven in bread, but of the teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees.
When Jesus came into the region of Caesarea Philippi, he asked his disciples, "Who do people say the Son of Man is?"
They said, "Some say John the Baptizer, others Elijah, and others Jeremiah or one of the prophets."
He said to them, "But you—who do you say I am?"
Simon Peter answered, "You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God."
Jesus answered him, "Blessed are you, Simon son of Jonah, because flesh and blood did not reveal this to you, but my Father who is in the heavens.
And I tell you that you are Peter, and on this rock I will build my assembly, and the gates of the realm of the dead will not overpower it.
I will give you the keys of the kingdom of the heavens, and whatever you bind on earth will have been bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will have been loosed in heaven."
Then he strictly ordered the disciples to tell no one that he is the Messiah.
From that time Jesus began to show his disciples that he must go to Jerusalem and suffer many things from the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and be raised on the third day.
Peter took him aside and began to rebuke him, saying, "God forbid, Lord! This will never happen to you."
But turning, he said to Peter, "Get behind me, Satan! You are a stumbling block to me, because you are not thinking God's thoughts but human thoughts."
Then Jesus said to his disciples, "If anyone wants to come after me, let him renounce himself and take up his cross and follow me.
For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for my sake will find it.
For what will a person gain if he acquires the whole world but forfeits his life? Or what will a person give in exchange for his life?
For the Son of Man is going to come in the glory of his Father with his angels, and then he will repay each person according to what they have done.
Truly I tell you, there are some standing here who will certainly not taste death until they see the Son of Man coming in his kingdom."

chapters.notes:
**"Unfaithful generation" (v. 4)**: The Greek μοιχαλίς literally means "adulterous," but this is prophetic covenant language (as in Hosea, Jeremiah, Ezekiel) describing Israel's spiritual unfaithfulness to God, her "husband." "Adulterous" in modern English sounds merely sexual; "unfaithful" captures the covenantal betrayal.

**"Assembly" (v. 18)**: Greek ἐκκλησία meant a called-out assembly or gathering—the term used in the Septuagint for Israel's congregation. "Church" carries too much institutional baggage for a first-century audience to have understood.

**"Gates of the realm of the dead" (v. 18)**: Greek πύλαι ᾅδου. "Hades" was the Greek term for the underworld/realm of the dead, equivalent to Hebrew Sheol. "Hell" in modern English implies a place of punishment, which is not what ᾅδης denotes. The "gates" of Hades represent death's power to hold the dead.

**"Will have been bound/loosed" (v. 19)**: The Greek construction (ἔσται δεδεμένον/λελυμένον) uses a future form of "to be" with a perfect passive participle. This suggests not simply "will be bound" but "will be in a state of already having been bound"—Peter's earthly decisions ratify heavenly realities rather than determining them.

**"God forbid" (v. 22)**: Greek Ἵλεώς σοι is an exclamation invoking divine mercy to prevent something—literally "May [God be] gracious to you!" The sense is "May God prevent this!" rather than the flat "Never!" of some translations.

**"Renounce himself" (v. 24)**: Greek ἀπαρνέομαι means to disown or utterly deny—the same verb used for Peter's denial of Jesus. "Deny himself" in modern English sounds like mere self-discipline; this is total self-renunciation.

**"Life" (vv. 25-26)**: Greek ψυχή can mean "soul" or "life" or "self." In this context about saving and losing, "life" captures the whole-person stakes better than "soul," which modern readers tend to limit to an immaterial component.

verses.text: And after six days, Jesus takes Peter and James and John his brother, and leads them up onto a high mountain by themselves.
And he was transformed before them, and his face shone like the sun, and his garments became white as light.
And suddenly Moses and Elijah appeared to them, conversing with him.
Peter spoke up and said to Jesus, "Lord, it is good for us to be here. If you wish, I will make three shelters here—one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah."
While he was still speaking, suddenly a luminous cloud overshadowed them, and suddenly a voice from the cloud said, "This is my Son, the Beloved, in whom I delight. Listen to him!"
When the disciples heard this, they fell face down and were utterly terrified.
But Jesus came and touched them and said, "Rise, and do not be afraid."
And lifting their eyes, they saw no one except Jesus alone.
As they were coming down from the mountain, Jesus commanded them, "Tell no one the vision until the Son of Man has been raised from the dead."
And the disciples asked him, "Why then do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?"
He answered, "Elijah is indeed coming and will restore all things.
But I tell you that Elijah has already come, and they did not recognize him but did to him whatever they pleased. So too the Son of Man is about to suffer at their hands."
Then the disciples understood that he was speaking to them about John the Baptist.
When they came to the crowd, a man approached him, falling on his knees before him
and saying, "Lord, have mercy on my son, because he is moonstruck and suffers terribly—for he often falls into fire and often into water.
I brought him to your disciples, and they were unable to heal him."
Jesus answered, "O faithless and twisted generation! How long will I be with you? How long must I bear with you? Bring him here to me."
And Jesus rebuked it, and the demon came out of him, and the boy was healed from that hour.
Then the disciples came to Jesus privately and said, "Why were we unable to cast it out?"

He said to them, "Because of your meager faith. For truly I tell you, if you have faith like a mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, 'Move from here to there,' and it will move, and nothing will be impossible for you."
While they were gathering in Galilee, Jesus said to them, "The Son of Man is about to be handed over into human hands,
and they will kill him, and on the third day he will be raised." And they were deeply grieved.
When they came to Capernaum, those who collected the two-drachma tax approached Peter and said, "Does your teacher not pay the two-drachma tax?"
He said, "Yes." And when he came into the house, Jesus spoke first, saying, "What do you think, Simon? From whom do earthly kings collect tolls and taxes—from their own sons or from others?"
When he said, "From others," Jesus said to him, "Then the sons are exempt.

But so that we do not give them offense, go to the sea and cast a hook, and take the first fish that comes up. When you open its mouth, you will find a four-drachma coin. Take that and give it to them for me and for you."

chapters.notes:
**"Transformed" (v. 2)**: The Greek μετεμορφώθη gives us our word "metamorphosis." The traditional "transfigured" is somewhat opaque in modern English; "transformed" captures the sense of a fundamental change in visible form.

**"Suddenly" (vv. 3, 5)**: Greek ἰδού is typically rendered "behold," but this is archaic. The word functions as an attention marker signaling something unexpected or dramatic. "Suddenly" preserves this narrative function.

**"The Beloved" (v. 5)**: Rendering ὁ ἀγαπητός as a title rather than merely an adjective ("my beloved son") captures the weight of this designation, which echoes the Servant in Isaiah and the binding of Isaac.

**"Listen to him" (v. 5)**: This echoes Deuteronomy 18:15, where Moses promises a prophet like himself whom Israel must "listen to"—an allusion the original audience would recognize.

**"Moonstruck" (v. 15)**: The Greek σεληνιάζεται literally means "affected by the moon" (from σελήνη, moon). While this referred to what we would call epileptic symptoms, rendering it simply as "epileptic" loses the ancient understanding. "Moonstruck" preserves the actual Greek term while remaining comprehensible.

**"Meager faith" (v. 20)**: Greek ὀλιγοπιστία means literally "little-faith" or "scant-faith." "Meager" captures both the smallness and the inadequacy better than "little," which sounds merely quantitative.

**"Two-drachma tax" / "four-drachma coin" (vv. 24, 27)**: The δίδραχμα was the temple tax (half-shekel) owed annually by every adult Jewish male. The στατήρ found in the fish was worth four drachmas—exactly enough for two people (Jesus and Peter). Retaining the monetary terms preserves the precise narrative logic.

**Verse 21 omitted**: Following the critical text, verse 21 ("But this kind does not go out except by prayer and fasting") is absent from the earliest manuscripts and appears to be a later addition.

verses.text: At that hour the disciples came to Jesus, saying, "Who then is greatest in the kingdom of the heavens?"
And calling a child over, he set the child in their midst
and said, "Truly I tell you, unless you turn and become like children, you will never enter the kingdom of the heavens.
So whoever humbles himself like this child—this one is the greatest in the kingdom of the heavens.
And whoever receives one such child in my name receives me.
"But whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble—it would be better for him to have a heavy millstone hung around his neck and to be drowned in the open sea.
Woe to the world because of stumbling blocks! For it is inevitable that stumbling blocks come, but woe to the person through whom the stumbling block comes.

"If your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away from you. It is better for you to enter into life maimed or lame than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into the eternal fire.
And if your eye causes you to stumble, tear it out and throw it away from you. It is better for you to enter into life one-eyed than to have two eyes and be thrown into the Gehenna of fire.
"See that you do not look down on one of these little ones. For I tell you that their angels in the heavens continually see the face of my Father who is in the heavens.
"What do you think? If a man has a hundred sheep and one of them wanders off, will he not leave the ninety-nine on the hills and go searching for the one that wandered?
And if he finds it, truly I tell you, he rejoices over it more than over the ninety-nine that did not wander.
In the same way, it is not the will of your Father who is in the heavens that one of these little ones should perish.
"If your brother sins against you, go and correct him between you and him alone. If he listens to you, you have won back your brother.
But if he does not listen, take with you one or two others, so that by the testimony of two or three witnesses every matter may be established.
If he refuses to listen to them, tell it to the assembly. And if he refuses to listen even to the assembly, let him be to you as a Gentile and a tax collector.
"Truly I tell you, whatever you bind on earth will have been bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will have been loosed in heaven.
Again, truly I tell you, if two of you agree on earth about any matter you ask for, it will be done for you by my Father who is in the heavens.
For where two or three are gathered in my name, there I am in their midst."
Then Peter came to him and said, "Lord, how many times will my brother sin against me and I must forgive him? Up to seven times?"
Jesus said to him, "I do not say to you up to seven times, but up to seventy-seven times.
"For this reason the kingdom of the heavens may be compared to a king who decided to settle accounts with his slaves.
When he began settling, one debtor was brought before him who owed ten thousand talents.
Since he had no way to repay, the master ordered him to be sold, along with his wife and children and everything he owned, and payment to be made.
So the slave fell down and was bowing before him, saying, 'Be patient with me and I will repay you everything.'
And the master of that slave, moved in his gut with compassion, released him and forgave him the debt.
"But that slave went out and found one of his fellow slaves who owed him a hundred denarii, and grabbing him by the throat, he was choking him, saying, 'Pay back what you owe!'
So his fellow slave fell down and begged him, saying, 'Be patient with me and I will repay you.'
But he refused. Instead he went and threw him into prison until he could repay what was owed.
"When his fellow slaves saw what had happened, they were deeply grieved, and they went and reported to their master everything that had taken place.
Then his master summoned him and said to him, 'Wicked slave! I forgave you that entire debt because you begged me.
Should you not also have shown mercy to your fellow slave, just as I showed mercy to you?'
And in anger his master handed him over to the torturers until he could repay all that was owed.
So also my heavenly Father will do to you, if each of you does not forgive your brother from your heart."

chapters.notes:
**"Causes to stumble" (vv. 6–9)**: The Greek σκανδαλίζω derives from σκάνδαλον, the trigger-stick of a trap. The word means to ensnare, trip up, or cause to fall into sin—not merely to offend or shock as modern "scandalize" suggests. "Cause to stumble" captures the original metaphor of tripping someone on their path.

**"Heavy millstone" (v. 6)**: Greek μύλος ὀνικός literally means "a millstone turned by a donkey"—a large commercial millstone as opposed to the small hand-mills used domestically. The point is the massive weight.

**"Gehenna" (v. 9)**: I have retained "Gehenna" rather than translating as "hell" because it refers specifically to the Valley of Hinnom (גֵּי בֶן־הִנֹּם) south of Jerusalem, associated with child sacrifice to Molech and later with fiery judgment. First-century Jewish listeners would have understood this specific geographical and theological reference.

**"Assembly" (v. 17)**: Greek ἐκκλησία here cannot mean "church" in the later institutional sense. In its Jewish context, it echoes the Hebrew קָהָל—the gathered community of God's people. "Assembly" preserves this without anachronism.

**"Will have been bound/loosed" (v. 18)**: The Greek uses future + perfect passive (ἔσται δεδεμένα/λελυμένα), suggesting the heavenly reality precedes or validates the earthly action. This reflects rabbinic authority language about declaring things forbidden or permitted.

**"Seventy-seven times" (v. 22)**: The Greek ἑβδομηκοντάκις ἑπτά could mean either "seventy times seven" (490) or "seventy-seven." The phrase deliberately echoes Lamech's boast of vengeance in Genesis 4:24 (LXX), inverting revenge into unlimited forgiveness.

**"Ten thousand talents" (v. 24)**: μύριοι (ten thousand) was the largest number Greeks had a single word for; τάλαντον was the largest unit of currency. This astronomical sum—perhaps equivalent to 200,000 years of a laborer's wages—is intentionally absurd and unpayable, heightening the contrast with the hundred denarii (roughly 100 days' wages) in verse 28.

**"Moved in his gut with compassion" (v. 27)**: Greek σπλαγχνίζομαι refers to being moved in one's σπλάγχνα—the bowels or internal organs understood as the seat of deep emotion. This is visceral, gut-level compassion, not merely cognitive sympathy.

**"Torturers" (v. 34)**: Greek βασανισταί refers specifically to those who extract payment through torture, not merely jailers. The word does not soften the severity of the judgment.

**Verse 11**: This verse is absent from the earliest manuscripts and is not included in the critical text. It appears to be a later scribal addition from Luke 19:10.

verses.text: And it happened that when Jesus finished these sayings, he departed from Galilee and came to the region of Judea beyond the Jordan.
Large crowds followed him, and he healed them there.
Some Pharisees came to him, testing him, and said, "Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife for any cause?"
He answered, "Have you not read that the one who created them from the beginning made them male and female,
and said, 'For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be bonded to his wife, and the two will become one flesh'?
So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore what God has yoked together, let no person separate."
They said to him, "Then why did Moses command giving a certificate of divorce and sending her away?"
He said to them, "Moses permitted you to divorce your wives because of your hardness of heart, but from the beginning it was not so.
And I say to you: whoever divorces his wife—not for sexual unfaithfulness—and marries another commits adultery, and the one who marries a divorced woman commits adultery."
The disciples said to him, "If this is the situation between a man and his wife, it is not advantageous to marry."
But he said to them, "Not everyone can accept this teaching, but only those to whom it has been given.

For there are eunuchs who were born that way from their mother's womb, and there are eunuchs who were made eunuchs by others, and there are eunuchs who have made themselves eunuchs for the sake of the kingdom of the heavens. Let the one who can accept this accept it."
Then children were brought to him so that he might lay his hands on them and pray. But the disciples rebuked them.
Jesus said, "Let the children come and do not prevent them from coming to me, for the kingdom of the heavens belongs to such as these."
And after laying his hands on them, he went on from there.
And look—someone came up to him and said, "Teacher, what good thing must I do to obtain eternal life?"
He said to him, "Why do you ask me about what is good? One alone is good. But if you want to enter into life, keep the commandments."
He said to him, "Which ones?" Jesus said, "You shall not murder, you shall not commit adultery, you shall not steal, you shall not bear false witness,
honor your father and mother, and love your neighbor as yourself."
The young man said to him, "All these I have kept. What am I still lacking?"
Jesus said to him, "If you want to be complete, go, sell your possessions and give to the destitute, and you will have treasure in the heavens—then come, follow me."
When the young man heard this, he went away grieving, for he had many estates.
Jesus said to his disciples, "Truly I tell you, it will be hard for a rich person to enter the kingdom of the heavens.
Again I tell you, it is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God."
When the disciples heard this, they were utterly astonished and said, "Who then can be saved?"
Jesus looked directly at them and said, "With humans this is impossible, but with God all things are possible."
Then Peter responded, "Look, we have left everything and followed you. What then will there be for us?"

Jesus said to them, "Truly I tell you, in the renewal of all things, when the Son of Man sits on his glorious throne, you who have followed me will also sit on twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
And everyone who has left houses or brothers or sisters or father or mother or children or fields for the sake of my name will receive a hundredfold and will inherit eternal life.
But many who are first will be last, and the last will be first."

chapters.notes:
**"For any cause" (v. 3)**: The phrase κατὰ πᾶσαν αἰτίαν reflects a specific first-century rabbinic debate. The school of Hillel interpreted Deuteronomy 24:1 ("something indecent") to permit divorce "for any cause," while Shammai restricted it to sexual misconduct. The Pharisees are testing which side Jesus takes.

**"Bonded" (v. 5)**: The Greek κολληθήσεται means to be glued or cemented together—a stronger image than simply "joined" or "united."

**"Yoked together" (v. 6)**: The verb συνέζευξεν derives from ζεῦγος (yoke), evoking the image of two animals joined under a single yoke, pulling together as one.

**"Sexual unfaithfulness" (v. 9)**: The Greek πορνεία is broader than "adultery" (μοιχεία) and can include various sexual transgressions. "Fornication" is archaic; "sexual immorality" is vague. Some scholars argue it refers specifically to marriages within prohibited degrees of kinship, but "sexual unfaithfulness" captures the marital context while preserving some breadth.

**"Accept" (vv. 11-12)**: The verb χωρέω literally means "to make room for" or "to have space for." Jesus uses it twice, creating a wordplay: not everyone has room for this teaching, but let the one who can make room, make room.

**"Complete" (v. 21)**: The Greek τέλειος means whole, mature, or having reached one's purpose—not merely "morally perfect" in the modern sense. The young man asks what he lacks (ὑστερῶ); Jesus tells him how to become complete.

**"Destitute" (v. 21)**: The Greek πτωχοῖς refers not merely to those with less money but to those reduced to begging—the desperately poor.

**"Estates" (v. 22)**: The Greek κτήματα specifically refers to landed property, not just possessions generally. This young man was a landowner.

**"Renewal of all things" (v. 28)**: The Greek παλιγγενεσία (literally "re-genesis" or "new birth") was used in Stoic philosophy for cosmic renewal. Here it refers to the eschatological restoration—what Jewish expectation called the world to come. "Regeneration" is too individualistic in modern English.

verses.text: "For the kingdom of the heavens is like a landowner who went out at dawn to hire workers for his vineyard.
After agreeing with the workers on a denarius for the day, he sent them into his vineyard.
And going out about the third hour, he saw others standing idle in the marketplace.
He said to them, 'You go into the vineyard too, and I will give you whatever is fair.'
So they went. Going out again about the sixth hour and the ninth hour, he did the same.
About the eleventh hour he went out and found others standing around, and he says to them, 'Why have you been standing here idle all day?'
They say to him, 'Because no one hired us.' He says to them, 'You go into the vineyard too.'
"When evening came, the master of the vineyard says to his manager, 'Call the workers and pay them their wages, beginning from the last to the first.'
When those hired about the eleventh hour came, they received a denarius each.
And when the first came, they expected to receive more—but they also received a denarius each.
Upon receiving it, they began grumbling against the landowner,
saying, 'These last ones worked a single hour, and you have made them equal to us who bore the burden of the day and the scorching heat!'
"But he answered one of them, 'Friend, I am not treating you unjustly. Did you not agree with me on a denarius?
Take what is yours and go. I choose to give to this last one the same as to you.
Am I not free to do what I wish with what is mine? Or is your eye evil because I am generous?'
"So the last will be first and the first will be last."
As Jesus was going up to Jerusalem, he took the twelve disciples aside privately, and on the road he said to them,
"Look, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be handed over to the chief priests and scribes. They will condemn him to death
and hand him over to the Gentiles to be mocked and flogged and crucified—and on the third day he will be raised."
Then the mother of Zebedee's sons approached him with her sons, kneeling before him and asking something of him.
He said to her, "What do you want?" She says to him, "Grant that these two sons of mine may sit, one at your right hand and one at your left, in your kingdom."
But Jesus answered, "You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup I am about to drink?" They say to him, "We are able."
He says to them, "My cup you will indeed drink. But to sit at my right and at my left is not mine to give; rather, it is for those for whom it has been prepared by my Father."
When the ten heard this, they became indignant at the two brothers.
But Jesus called them to himself and said, "You know that the rulers of the nations lord it over them, and their great ones wield authority over them.
It shall not be so among you. Rather, whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant,
and whoever wants to be first among you must be your slave—
just as the Son of Man did not come to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom in place of many."
As they were leaving Jericho, a large crowd followed him.
And look—two blind men sitting beside the road heard that Jesus was passing by and cried out, "Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!"
The crowd rebuked them, telling them to be silent. But they cried out all the louder, "Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!"
Jesus stopped and called to them and said, "What do you want me to do for you?"
They say to him, "Lord, that our eyes may be opened."
Moved with compassion, Jesus touched their eyes, and immediately they received their sight and followed him.

chapters.notes:
**"Is your eye evil" (v. 15)**: The Greek ὁ ὀφθαλμός σου πονηρός preserves a Semitic idiom (עין רעה) referring to envy and stinginess—the opposite of the "good eye" that signifies generosity. Most translations render this as "envious," which captures the sense but loses the idiom. I retained the literal phrase because the context makes the meaning clear: "Is your eye evil because I am generous?"

**"Friend" (v. 13)**: The Greek ἑταῖρε is not the warm term φίλος but a more formal, even cool address. In Matthew, Jesus uses it for the man without wedding garments (22:12) and for Judas at his betrayal (26:50). It carries a note of distance, perhaps disappointment—closer to "my man" than "dear friend."

**"Lord it over... wield authority over" (v. 25)**: Both verbs (κατακυριεύουσιν, κατεξουσιάζουσιν) carry the intensive prefix κατα-, suggesting dominance and oppression rather than mere leadership. "Wield authority" captures the forceful exercise of power better than simple "exercise authority."

**"In place of many" (v. 28)**: The preposition ἀντί carries substitutionary force—"instead of," "in exchange for." While "for many" is not wrong, "in place of many" makes the substitutionary nature of λύτρον (ransom) more explicit.

**"Moved with compassion" (v. 34)**: The verb σπλαγχνίζομαι derives from σπλάγχνα (intestines/gut), denoting visceral, deep-seated compassion—not mere pity but something felt in the core of one's being.

**Historic present tense**: The Greek frequently shifts to present tense in narrative (λέγει, "he says") for vividness. I preserved this in most dialogue introductions to maintain the text's immediacy.

verses.text: And when they drew near to Jerusalem and came to Bethphage at the Mount of Olives, then Jesus sent two disciples,
saying to them, "Go into the village opposite you, and immediately you will find a donkey tied up, and a colt with her. Untie them and bring them to me.
And if anyone says anything to you, say, 'The Lord has need of them.' And he will send them at once."
Now this took place so that what was spoken through the prophet might be fulfilled:
"Tell the daughter of Zion: Look—your king is coming to you, gentle and mounted on a donkey, on a colt, the offspring of a beast of burden."
The disciples went and did just as Jesus instructed them.
They brought the donkey and the colt and placed their cloaks on them, and he sat on the cloaks.
Most of the crowd spread their own cloaks on the road, while others were cutting branches from the trees and spreading them on the road.
And the crowds going ahead of him and those following kept crying out: "Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest heavens!"
And when he entered Jerusalem, the whole city was shaken, saying, "Who is this?"
And the crowds kept saying, "This is the prophet Jesus, from Nazareth of Galilee."
And Jesus entered the temple and drove out all those selling and buying in the temple, and he overturned the tables of the money changers and the seats of those selling doves.
And he says to them, "It is written, 'My house shall be called a house of prayer,' but you are making it a den of bandits."
And blind and lame people came to him in the temple, and he healed them.
But when the chief priests and the scribes saw the wonders he performed and the children crying out in the temple, "Hosanna to the Son of David," they were indignant
and said to him, "Do you hear what these are saying?" Jesus says to them, "Yes. Have you never read, 'Out of the mouths of infants and nursing babies you have fashioned praise'?"
And leaving them behind, he went out of the city to Bethany and spent the night there.
Early in the morning, returning to the city, he grew hungry.
And seeing a fig tree by the road, he went up to it and found nothing on it except leaves only. And he says to it, "May fruit never come from you again." And the fig tree withered at once.
When the disciples saw this, they were astonished, saying, "How did the fig tree wither so suddenly?"

Jesus answered them, "Truly I tell you, if you have faith and do not waver, not only will you do what was done to the fig tree, but even if you say to this mountain, 'Be lifted up and thrown into the sea,' it will happen.
And whatever you ask in prayer, believing, you will receive."

When he came into the temple, the chief priests and the elders of the people approached him while he was teaching, saying, "By what authority are you doing these things? And who gave you this authority?"
Jesus answered them, "I too will ask you one question; if you tell me the answer, I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
The baptism of John—where did it come from? From heaven, or from human origin?" They deliberated among themselves: "If we say, 'From heaven,' he will say to us, 'Then why did you not believe him?'
But if we say, 'From human origin,' we fear the crowd—for they all regard John as a prophet."
So they answered Jesus, "We do not know." He said to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things."
"But what do you think? A man had two sons. He went to the first and said, 'Son, go work in the vineyard today.'
He answered, 'I will not'—but later, having a change of heart, he went.
The father went to the second and said the same. He answered, 'I will, sir'—but did not go.
Which of the two did the will of the father?" They say, "The first." Jesus says to them, "Truly I tell you, the tax collectors and the prostitutes are going into the kingdom of God ahead of you.

For John came to you walking in the way of righteousness, and you did not believe him. But the tax collectors and the prostitutes believed him. And you, even after seeing this, did not have a change of heart afterward so as to believe him."
"Hear another parable. There was a landowner who planted a vineyard. He put a fence around it, dug a winepress in it, and built a watchtower. Then he leased it to tenant farmers and went abroad.
When the season for fruit drew near, he sent his slaves to the tenant farmers to collect his produce.
But the tenant farmers seized his slaves: one they beat, one they killed, one they stoned.
Again he sent other slaves, more than the first group, and they did the same to them.
Finally he sent his son to them, thinking, 'They will respect my son.'
But the tenant farmers, seeing the son, said among themselves, 'This is the heir. Come, let us kill him and seize his inheritance!'
And they grabbed him, threw him out of the vineyard, and killed him.
When the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those tenant farmers?"
They say to him, "Those wretches—he will bring them to a wretched end, and he will lease the vineyard to other tenant farmers who will render to him the produce at the proper times."
Jesus says to them, "Have you never read in the Scriptures: 'The stone the builders rejected— this has become the cornerstone. This came from the Lord, and it is marvelous in our eyes'?
For this reason I tell you, the kingdom of God will be taken from you and given to a nation that produces its fruit.
And whoever falls on this stone will be shattered; and whomever it falls upon, it will scatter like chaff."
When the chief priests and the Pharisees heard his parables, they recognized that he was speaking about them.
And though they sought to arrest him, they feared the crowds, since they regarded him as a prophet.

chapters.notes:
**"The Lord has need of them" (v. 3)**: The Greek κύριος carries productive ambiguity—it could mean simply "the owner" or the more theologically loaded "the Lord." Matthew's readers would hear both senses simultaneously.

**"He sat on the cloaks" (v. 7)**: The Greek αὐτῶν (them) is plural and grammatically ambiguous, leading to occasional confusion about whether Jesus rode both animals. In context, it refers to the cloaks placed on the animals. I have made this explicit.

**"Shaken" (v. 10)**: ἐσείσθη shares its root with "seismic"—this is earthquake language. The city is not merely curious but deeply disturbed.

**"Den of bandits" (v. 13)**: The Greek λῃσταί refers to violent robbers or brigands, not petty thieves. Jesus quotes Jeremiah 7:11, where the prophet condemned those who made the temple a refuge while practicing injustice. The charge is about violent exploitation, not mere dishonesty.

**"Fashioned praise" (v. 16)**: κατηρτίσω means to prepare, complete, or fashion—God has actively prepared praise from children's mouths, not merely permitted it.

**"Do not waver" (v. 21)**: διακριθῆτε means to be divided within oneself, to be torn between two minds. This captures the internal conflict better than simple "doubt."

**"Having a change of heart" (vv. 29, 32)**: μεταμεληθείς and μετεμελήθητε indicate regret leading to changed behavior—distinct from μετανοέω (repentance). The parallel between the son's "change of heart" and what the leaders refused creates a verbal link in Greek that I have preserved.

**"Those wretches—he will bring them to a wretched end" (v. 41)**: Κακοὺς κακῶς ἀπολέσει is a figura etymologica (wordplay using cognates): literally "evil ones evilly he will destroy." The translation attempts to preserve this rhetorical punch.

**"A nation" (v. 43)**: ἔθνει is singular, not plural "nations" (ἔθνη). This is theologically significant—the kingdom passes to a single people (the church), not generically to Gentiles.

**"Scatter like chaff" (v. 44)**: λικμήσει refers to the winnowing process—being scattered to the wind like crushed grain husks. This evokes complete destruction and dispersal.

verses.text: And responding, Jesus again spoke to them in parables, saying:
"The kingdom of the heavens may be compared to a king who prepared a wedding celebration for his son.
He sent his slaves to call those who had been invited to the wedding, but they refused to come.

Again he sent other slaves, saying, 'Tell those who have been invited: Look, I have prepared my feast—my oxen and fattened cattle have been slaughtered, and everything is ready. Come to the wedding celebration.'
But they paid no attention and went off—one to his own field, another to his business.
The rest seized his slaves, mistreated them violently, and killed them.
The king was enraged, and sending his armies, he destroyed those murderers and burned their city.
Then he says to his slaves, 'The wedding feast is ready, but those who were invited were not worthy.
So go to the places where the roads lead out, and invite to the wedding celebration as many as you find.'
And those slaves went out into the roads and gathered everyone they found, both wicked and good, and the wedding hall was filled with guests reclining at table.
"But when the king came in to observe those reclining at table, he saw there a man not wearing wedding clothing.
And he says to him, 'Comrade, how did you get in here without wedding clothing?' And he was silenced.
Then the king said to the attendants, 'Bind his feet and hands and throw him out into the outer darkness. There will be weeping and grinding of teeth.'
For many are called, but few are chosen."
Then the Pharisees went and plotted together how they might trap him with a statement.

They send their disciples to him along with the Herodians, saying, "Teacher, we know that you are truthful and teach the way of God in truth, and you defer to no one, for you do not regard people's standing.
So tell us what you think: Is it permitted to pay the census tax to Caesar, or not?"
But Jesus, knowing their malice, said, "Why are you testing me, you performers?
Show me the coin used for the tax." And they brought him a denarius.
And he says to them, "Whose image is this, and whose inscription?"
They say to him, "Caesar's." Then he says to them, "So give back to Caesar what belongs to Caesar, and to God what belongs to God."
And when they heard this, they were amazed, and leaving him, they went away.
On that day Sadducees came to him—those who say there is no resurrection—and they questioned him,
saying, "Teacher, Moses said, 'If someone dies without having children, his brother shall marry his widow and raise up offspring for his brother.'
Now there were seven brothers among us. The first married and died, and having no offspring, left his wife to his brother.
Likewise the second, and the third, down through the seventh.
Last of all, the woman died.
In the resurrection, then, whose wife of the seven will she be? For they all had her."
Jesus answered them, "You are deceived, knowing neither the scriptures nor the power of God.
For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels of God in heaven.
But concerning the resurrection of the dead, have you not read what was spoken to you by God, saying,
'I am the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob'? He is not God of the dead but of the living."
And when the crowds heard this, they were astounded at his teaching.
Now when the Pharisees heard that he had silenced the Sadducees, they gathered together.
And one of them, an expert in the law, tested him with a question:
"Teacher, which commandment in the law is greatest?"
He said to him, "'You shall love the Lord your God with your whole heart and with your whole soul and with your whole mind.'
This is the greatest and first commandment.
And a second is like it: 'You shall love your neighbor as yourself.'
On these two commandments hang the whole law and the prophets."
Now while the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus questioned them,
saying, "What do you think about the Messiah? Whose son is he?" They say to him, "David's."
He says to them, "How then does David, speaking by the Spirit, call him Lord, saying,
'The Lord said to my Lord: Sit at my right hand until I place your enemies beneath your feet'?
If then David calls him Lord, how is he his son?"
And no one was able to answer him a word, nor did anyone dare to question him any longer from that day on.

chapters.notes:
**"Wedding celebration" (vv. 2-10)**: The Greek γάμους is plural, referring not to a single ceremony but to the multi-day festivities typical of ancient weddings. "Wedding celebration" or "wedding feast" captures this better than simply "wedding."

**"Comrade" (v. 12)**: The Greek Ἑταῖρε appears three times in Matthew (here, 20:13, 26:50), always in contexts of rebuke or tension. It's not the warm φίλος ("friend") but a more distant address—something like "my good man" or "companion." It signals relationship while creating distance. "Comrade" captures this ambivalent tone.

**"Was silenced" (v. 12)**: The verb ἐφιμώθη (also used in v. 34 of the Sadducees) means "was muzzled"—rendered speechless, as if gagged. The passive voice suggests he had no defense to offer.

**"Performers" (v. 18)**: As noted in the guidelines, ὑποκριταί refers to stage actors. The Pharisees and Herodians are performing a role—feigning sincerity while plotting entrapment.

**"Do not regard people's standing" (v. 16)**: The Greek οὐ γὰρ βλέπεις εἰς πρόσωπον ἀνθρώπων ("you do not look at the face of people") is a Semitic idiom for showing no partiality based on status. The flatterers are (ironically) speaking truth—Jesus genuinely shows no favoritism.

**"Give back" (v. 21)**: The verb Ἀπόδοτε (from ἀποδίδωμι) means "render back, return, repay"—not merely "give." It implies returning what is already owed or what already belongs to someone.

**"You are deceived" (v. 29)**: Πλανᾶσθε means "you are wandering, going astray, being led into error." This is stronger than simply "you are wrong"—it suggests they've been led off the path.

**"Messiah" (v. 42)**: The Greek τοῦ χριστοῦ ("the Christ") is the Greek translation of the Hebrew "Messiah" (anointed one). Using "Messiah" here clarifies that Jesus is asking about the expected Davidic deliverer, not making a Christian confession.

**"Beneath your feet" (v. 44)**: The SBLGNT has ὑποκάτω ("beneath") rather than ὑποπόδιον ("footstool"). This follows the reading of important early manuscripts.

verses.text: Then Jesus spoke to the crowds and to his disciples,
saying: "The scribes and the Pharisees have seated themselves on Moses's seat.
So everything they tell you, do and observe—but do not act according to their deeds, for they speak but do not act.
They tie up heavy loads and place them on people's shoulders, yet they themselves are unwilling to lift a finger to move them.
All their deeds they do to be watched by people: they widen their phylacteries and lengthen their tassels,
and they love the place of honor at banquets and the front seats in the synagogues
and the greetings in the marketplaces and being called 'Rabbi' by people.
"But you—do not be called 'Rabbi,' for one is your teacher, and you are all brothers.
And do not call anyone on earth your 'Father,' for one is your Father—the heavenly one.
Nor be called 'instructors,' for one is your instructor—the Messiah.
The greatest among you will be your servant.
Whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be exalted.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, performers! For you lock up the kingdom of the heavens in front of people; you yourselves do not enter, nor do you allow those entering to go in.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, performers! For you cross sea and dry land to make one convert, and when he becomes one, you make him twice as much a child of Gehenna as yourselves.
"Woe to you, blind guides, who say, 'Whoever swears by the sanctuary—it means nothing; but whoever swears by the gold of the sanctuary is bound.'
Fools and blind! Which is greater—the gold, or the sanctuary that consecrates the gold?
And, 'Whoever swears by the altar—it means nothing; but whoever swears by the gift upon it is bound.'
Blind ones! Which is greater—the gift, or the altar that consecrates the gift?
So the one who swears by the altar swears by it and by everything upon it;
and the one who swears by the sanctuary swears by it and by the one dwelling in it;
and the one who swears by heaven swears by the throne of God and by the one seated upon it.

"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, performers! For you tithe mint and dill and cumin, but have neglected the weightier matters of the Law—justice and mercy and faithfulness. These you should have done without neglecting the others.
Blind guides! Straining out the gnat but swallowing the camel.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, performers! For you clean the outside of the cup and dish, but inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence.
Blind Pharisee! First clean the inside of the cup and dish, so that the outside may become clean as well.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, performers! For you are like whitewashed tombs, which on the outside appear beautiful, but inside are full of dead bones and every kind of uncleanness.
So you also—on the outside you appear righteous to people, but inside you are full of pretense and lawlessness.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, performers! For you build the tombs of the prophets and decorate the monuments of the righteous,
and you say, 'If we had lived in the days of our fathers, we would not have been their partners in shedding the blood of the prophets.'
So you testify against yourselves that you are sons of those who murdered the prophets.
Fill up, then, the measure of your fathers!
Serpents! Brood of vipers! How will you escape the judgment of Gehenna?
"Therefore—look!—I am sending to you prophets and sages and scribes. Some of them you will kill and crucify, and some of them you will flog in your synagogues and pursue from city to city,

so that upon you may come all the righteous blood poured out on the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zechariah son of Barachiah, whom you murdered between the sanctuary and the altar.
Truly I tell you, all these things will come upon this generation.
"Jerusalem, Jerusalem—she who kills the prophets and stones those sent to her! How often I wanted to gather your children the way a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, and you were unwilling!
Look—your house is left to you desolate.
For I tell you, you will certainly not see me from now until you say, 'Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord.'"

chapters.notes:
**"Performers" (vv. 13, 15, 23, 25, 27, 29)**: Greek ὑποκριταί originally meant stage actors—people playing a role for an audience. The modern English "hypocrite" suggests inward duplicity, but Jesus's critique is that their religion *is* the performance. The noun ὑποκρίσεως in v. 28 becomes "pretense" to maintain this theatrical sense.

**"Seated themselves on Moses's seat" (v. 2)**: The aorist ἐκάθισαν suggests they have taken this position of authority, perhaps with a note of presumption. Some synagogues had a literal stone seat for the authoritative Torah teacher.

**"Phylacteries" and "tassels" (v. 5)**: φυλακτήρια are the tefillin—small leather boxes containing Scripture worn during prayer. κράσπεδα are the tzitzit—ritual fringes commanded in Numbers 15:38-39. Widening and lengthening these made one's piety more publicly visible.

**"Instructors" (v. 10)**: Greek καθηγηταί is distinct from διδάσκαλος (teacher) in v. 8—it suggests a master-guide or authoritative leader. The three prohibited titles (Rabbi, Father, Instructor) represent escalating claims to spiritual authority.

**"Sanctuary" (vv. 16-21, 35)**: Greek ναός refers to the sanctuary proper—the inner sacred building—distinct from ἱερόν (the entire temple complex). This precision matters for the oath-swearing logic: swearing by the sanctuary implicitly invokes God who dwells there.

**"Gehenna" (vv. 15, 33)**: The Valley of Hinnom outside Jerusalem, associated with child sacrifice in Israel's past and later used as a metaphor for divine judgment. Preserving the term rather than translating "hell" avoids importing later theological concepts.

**"Gnat...camel" (v. 24)**: In the underlying Aramaic, these words likely formed a pun: *qalma* (gnat) and *gamla* (camel). The absurdist image is deliberate—meticulously filtering out the smallest impurity while gulping down the largest unclean animal.

**"Weightier matters" (v. 23)**: τὰ βαρύτερα—literally "the heavier things." This echoes rabbinic discussions about which commandments carry more weight. Note the contrast with the "heavy burdens" (φορτία βαρέα) they impose on others in v. 4.

**"Whitewashed tombs" (v. 27)**: Tombs were whitewashed before Passover so pilgrims could see and avoid them, preventing ritual defilement from corpse-impurity. The image is devastating: what makes them visible is itself evidence of the death within.

**"Fill up the measure" (v. 32)**: πληρώσατε is imperative—a grim permission or prophetic irony: "Go ahead, complete what your fathers started."

**Verse 14 omitted**: Following the critical text (SBLGNT/NA28), which recognizes this verse as a scribal addition from the parallel in Mark 12:40/Luke 20:47.

verses.text: And Jesus, going out from the temple, was departing, and his disciples came to him to point out to him the buildings of the temple.
But he responded and said to them, "Do you not see all these things? Truly I tell you, not one stone will be left here upon another that will not be torn down."

And as he was sitting on the Mount of Olives, the disciples came to him privately, saying, "Tell us, when will these things be? And what will be the sign of your arrival and of the completion of the age?"
And Jesus answered them, "Watch out that no one leads you astray.
For many will come in my name, saying, 'I am the Messiah,' and will lead many astray.
And you will hear of wars and reports of wars. See that you are not alarmed, for this must happen, but the end is not yet.
For nation will rise against nation and kingdom against kingdom, and there will be famines and earthquakes in various places.
But all these things are the beginning of labor pains.
"Then they will hand you over to affliction and will kill you, and you will be hated by all the nations because of my name.
And then many will fall away, and will betray one another and hate one another.
And many false prophets will arise and lead many astray.
And because lawlessness will be multiplied, the love of most will grow cold.
But the one who endures to the end—this one will be saved.
And this good news of the kingdom will be proclaimed in the whole inhabited world as a testimony to all the nations, and then the end will come.
"So when you see the abomination of desolation—spoken of through Daniel the prophet—standing in the holy place (let the reader understand),
then let those in Judea flee to the mountains.
The one on the rooftop must not go down to retrieve things from his house,
and the one in the field must not turn back to get his cloak.
But woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing in those days.
And pray that your flight may not happen in winter or on a Sabbath.
For then there will be great affliction, such as has not occurred from the beginning of the world until now, and never will occur again.
And if those days had not been cut short, no flesh would be saved. But for the sake of the chosen ones, those days will be cut short.
"Then if anyone says to you, 'Look, here is the Messiah!' or 'Here he is!'—do not believe it.
For false messiahs and false prophets will arise and will produce great signs and wonders, so as to lead astray, if possible, even the chosen ones.
Look—I have told you beforehand.
So if they say to you, 'Look, he is in the wilderness,' do not go out. 'Look, he is in the inner rooms'—do not believe it.
For just as lightning comes forth from the east and flashes as far as the west, so will be the arrival of the Son of Man.
Wherever the corpse is, there the vultures will gather.
"Immediately after the affliction of those days, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light, and the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken.
And then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in heaven, and then all the tribes of the earth will mourn, and they will see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.
And he will send out his angels with a great trumpet blast, and they will gather together his chosen ones from the four winds, from one end of the heavens to the other.
"Now learn the lesson from the fig tree: when its branch has already become tender and it puts forth its leaves, you know that summer is near.
So also you—when you see all these things, know that it is near, at the very doors.
Truly I tell you that this generation will certainly not pass away until all these things have happened.
Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.
"But concerning that day and hour, no one knows—not the angels of the heavens, nor the Son—except the Father alone.
For just as the days of Noah were, so will be the arrival of the Son of Man.
For as in those days before the flood they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day when Noah entered the ark,
and they knew nothing until the flood came and swept them all away—so will be the arrival of the Son of Man.
Then two men will be in the field: one is taken and one is left.
Two women will be grinding at the mill: one is taken and one is left.
"Keep watch, therefore, because you do not know on what day your Lord is coming.
But know this: if the master of the house had known in what watch of the night the thief was coming, he would have stayed awake and would not have let his house be broken into.
For this reason, you also must be ready, because the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.
"Who then is the faithful and prudent servant whom the master has put in charge of his household to give them their food at the proper time?
Blessed is that servant whom his master, when he comes, finds doing so.
Truly I tell you, he will put him in charge of all his possessions.
But if that wicked servant says in his heart, 'My master is delayed,'
and begins to beat his fellow servants, and eats and drinks with drunkards,
the master of that servant will come on a day he does not expect and at an hour he does not know,
and will cut him in two and assign his portion with the performers. There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth."

chapters.notes:
**"Arrival" (v. 3, 27, 37, 39)**: The Greek παρουσία literally means "presence" or "being present," and in Hellenistic usage it was the technical term for a royal visit or the arrival of a king. "Coming" flattens this into mere motion; "arrival" better captures the sense of an awaited, momentous appearing.

**"Completion of the age" (v. 3)**: συντελείας τοῦ αἰῶνος refers not to the end of the physical world but to the consummation or fulfillment of the present age—a Jewish apocalyptic concept of the turning of the ages.

**"Labor pains" (v. 8)**: ὠδίνων specifically means birth pangs. This connects to the Jewish concept of the "birth pangs of the Messiah"—the travail preceding the messianic age. The metaphor is lost with generic "sorrows" or "troubles."

**"Fall away" (v. 10)**: σκανδαλισθήσονται derives from σκάνδαλον, a trap-trigger. The sense is being caused to stumble or being ensnared—a loss of faith under pressure, not mere offense.

**"The many" (v. 12)**: τῶν πολλῶν could mean "most people" but "the many" preserves the construction and echoes the repetition of πολλοί throughout this section.

**"Inner rooms" (v. 26)**: ταμείοις refers to the innermost, most private chambers of a house—storerooms or hidden spaces. The point is that the Messiah's arrival cannot be secret or localized.

**"Vultures" (v. 28)**: ἀετοί can mean eagles or vultures. Context (gathering around a corpse) strongly suggests vultures. This appears to be a proverbial saying about the obviousness and inevitability of what is coming.

**"Cut him in two" (v. 51)**: διχοτομήσει literally means to cut in two, to bisect. Some translations soften this to "punish severely," but the Greek is graphic—likely describing execution or referencing the punishment of dismemberment.

**"Performers" (v. 51)**: ὑποκριτῶν—as noted in the guidelines, these are play-actors, those whose piety is theatrical. The wicked servant's fate is with those whose religion was performance rather than substance.

verses.text: Then the kingdom of the heavens will be compared to ten young women who took their torches and went out to meet the bridegroom.
Five of them were foolish and five were wise.
For the foolish ones, when they took their torches, did not take oil with them.
But the wise ones took oil in flasks along with their torches.
While the bridegroom was delayed, they all grew drowsy and fell asleep.
But in the middle of the night a cry rang out: "Look! The bridegroom! Come out to meet him!"
Then all those young women rose and trimmed their torches.
The foolish ones said to the wise, "Give us some of your oil, because our torches are going out."
But the wise ones answered, saying, "No—there may not be enough for both us and you. Go instead to the merchants and buy some for yourselves."
But while they were going away to buy, the bridegroom arrived, and those who were ready went in with him to the wedding feast, and the door was shut.
Later the rest of the young women also came, saying, "Lord, lord, open up for us!"
But he answered and said, "Truly I tell you, I do not know you."
Therefore keep watch, because you do not know the day or the hour.
For it is like a man going on a journey who called his own slaves and entrusted his property to them.
To one he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one—to each according to his own ability—and he went away. Immediately
the one who had received the five talents went and put them to work and gained five more.
Likewise the one with the two gained two more.
But the one who had received the one talent went away, dug a hole in the ground, and hid his master's money.
Now after a long time the master of those slaves comes and settles accounts with them.
The one who had received the five talents came forward and brought five more talents, saying, "Master, you entrusted five talents to me. Look—I have gained five more talents."
His master said to him, "Well done, good and trustworthy slave! You were trustworthy over a little; I will put you in charge of much. Enter into the joy of your master."
The one with the two talents also came forward and said, "Master, you entrusted two talents to me. Look—I have gained two more talents."
His master said to him, "Well done, good and trustworthy slave! You were trustworthy over a little; I will put you in charge of much. Enter into the joy of your master."
Then the one who had received the one talent also came forward and said, "Master, I knew you to be a hard man, harvesting where you did not sow and gathering where you did not scatter seed.
And being afraid, I went away and hid your talent in the ground. Look—you have what is yours."
But his master answered and said to him, "Wicked and lazy slave! You knew that I harvest where I did not sow and gather where I did not scatter?
Then you ought to have deposited my money with the bankers, and when I came I would have received back what was mine with interest.
Therefore take the talent from him and give it to the one who has the ten talents.
For to everyone who has, more will be given and they will have abundance. But from the one who does not have, even what they have will be taken from them.
And throw the worthless slave into the outer darkness. There will be weeping and grinding of teeth."
When the Son of Man comes in his glory, and all the angels with him, then he will sit on his glorious throne.
All the nations will be gathered before him, and he will separate them from one another, just as the shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
He will place the sheep on his right and the goats on his left.
Then the king will say to those on his right, "Come, you who are blessed by my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world.
For I was hungry and you gave me something to eat. I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink. I was a stranger and you took me in.
I was naked and you clothed me. I was sick and you looked after me. I was in prison and you came to me."
Then the righteous will answer him, saying, "Lord, when did we see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you drink?
When did we see you a stranger and take you in, or naked and clothe you?
When did we see you sick or in prison and come to you?"
And the king will answer and say to them, "Truly I tell you, inasmuch as you did it for one of the least of these brothers of mine, you did it for me."
Then he will also say to those on his left, "Depart from me, you who are cursed, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels.
For I was hungry and you did not give me anything to eat. I was thirsty and you did not give me anything to drink.
I was a stranger and you did not take me in. I was naked and you did not clothe me. I was sick and in prison and you did not look after me."
Then they too will answer, saying, "Lord, when did we see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison and not serve you?"
Then he will answer them, saying, "Truly I tell you, inasmuch as you did not do it for one of the least of these, neither did you do it for me."
And these will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life.

chapters.notes:
**"Young women" (v. 1, 7, 11)**: Greek παρθένοι specifically denotes unmarried young women (virgins). In the context of a wedding procession, these are attendants awaiting the bridegroom—likely young women from the bride's household. "Virgins" in modern English carries connotations that distract from the narrative function.

**"Torches" (v. 1, 3, 4, 7, 8)**: Greek λαμπάδας can mean lamps or torches. In the context of a nighttime wedding procession, these were likely torches carried by the attendants to light the bridegroom's way. The detail about oil and the torches "going out" (σβέννυνται, v. 8) fits torches that needed continual oil.

**"Trimmed" (v. 7)**: Greek ἐκόσμησαν means to arrange, put in order, or prepare. For torches, this would involve adjusting the wick and adding oil—"trimmed" captures this practical action.

**"Talents" (v. 15ff)**: A talent was an enormous sum—roughly 6,000 denarii, or about twenty years' wages for a laborer. The word has become so familiar that its shocking scale is lost, but I retain it as the most recognizable term. The master entrusts staggering wealth.

**"Trustworthy" (v. 21, 23)**: Greek πιστός can mean "faithful" or "trustworthy." In the context of financial stewardship, "trustworthy" better captures the semantic field—the slave proved reliable with what was entrusted to him.

**"Settles accounts" (v. 19)**: Greek συναίρει λόγον is commercial terminology for balancing the books—a reckoning of debts and assets.

**"Lazy" (v. 26)**: Greek ὀκνηρός means hesitant, shrinking back, slothful. Combined with πονηρός (wicked), it characterizes the slave as both morally culpable and practically useless.

**"Grinding of teeth" (v. 30)**: Greek βρυγμός denotes grinding or gnashing—an expression of anguish or rage, not merely chattering from cold.

**"Goats" (v. 32, 33)**: Verse 32 uses ἐρίφων (mature male goats), verse 33 uses ἐρίφια (young goats). The distinction may simply be stylistic variation, but sheep and goats were commonly herded together in Palestine and separated at night.

**"Took me in" (v. 35, 38, 43)**: Greek συνηγάγετε literally means "gathered me in"—offering hospitality and shelter to a stranger. This is more active than merely "welcoming."

**"Looked after" (v. 36, 43)**: Greek ἐπεσκέψασθε means to visit with care and concern, to look after someone's welfare—not merely a social call but attentive care for the sick.

**"The least of these brothers of mine" (v. 40)**: The Greek τῶν ἐλαχίστων is superlative—the very least, the most insignificant. Note that "brothers of mine" appears in v. 40 but is absent in v. 45, which simply says "the least of these."

verses.text: When Jesus had finished all these words, he said to his disciples:
"You know that in two days the Passover takes place, and the Son of Man is being handed over to be crucified."
Then the chief priests and the elders of the people gathered in the courtyard of the high priest, the one called Caiaphas,
and they conspired to seize Jesus by deception and kill him.
But they were saying, "Not during the festival, so that there will not be an uproar among the people."
Now while Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,
a woman came to him with an alabaster jar of very expensive perfumed oil and poured it over his head as he reclined at table.
When the disciples saw this, they were indignant, saying, "Why this waste?
For this could have been sold for a large sum and given to the poor."
But Jesus, aware of this, said to them, "Why are you causing trouble for this woman? She has done a beautiful deed for me.
For you always have the poor with you, but you will not always have me.
By pouring this perfumed oil on my body, she has prepared me for burial.
Truly I tell you, wherever this good news is proclaimed in the whole world, what she has done will also be spoken of as a memorial to her."
Then one of the twelve, the one called Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests
and said, "What are you willing to give me if I hand him over to you?" And they set out for him thirty silver pieces.
From that time he was looking for an opportunity to hand him over.
On the first day of Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Jesus saying, "Where do you want us to prepare for you to eat the Passover?"
He said, "Go into the city to a certain man and say to him, 'The Teacher says: My appointed time is near. I am keeping the Passover at your house with my disciples.'"
And the disciples did as Jesus directed them, and they prepared the Passover.
When evening came, he was reclining at table with the twelve.
And while they were eating, he said, "Truly I tell you that one of you will hand me over."
And being deeply grieved, they began to say to him, one after another, "Surely not I, Lord?"
He answered, "The one who dipped his hand in the bowl with me—this one will hand me over.
The Son of Man goes away just as it is written about him, but woe to that man through whom the Son of Man is handed over. It would have been better for that man if he had not been born."
Then Judas, the one handing him over, answered and said, "Surely not I, Rabbi?" He said to him, "You have said it."
While they were eating, Jesus took bread, and after blessing it, broke it and gave it to the disciples and said, "Take, eat; this is my body."
