And taking a cup and giving thanks, he gave it to them, saying, "Drink from it, all of you,
for this is my blood of the covenant, which is being poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins.
I tell you, I will certainly not drink from this fruit of the vine from now on until that day when I drink it new with you in the kingdom of my Father."
And after singing a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
Then Jesus said to them, "All of you will fall away because of me this night, for it is written: 'I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.'
But after I am raised, I will go ahead of you to Galilee."
Peter answered him, "Even if all fall away because of you, I will never fall away."
Jesus said to him, "Truly I tell you that this very night, before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times."
Peter said to him, "Even if I must die with you, I will certainly not deny you." And all the disciples said the same.
Then Jesus came with them to a place called Gethsemane, and he said to the disciples, "Sit here while I go over there to pray."
And taking along Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, he began to be grieved and deeply distressed.
Then he said to them, "My soul is overwhelmed with sorrow to the point of death. Stay here and keep watch with me."
And going forward a little, he fell on his face, praying and saying, "My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass from me. Yet not as I will, but as you will."
And he came to the disciples and found them sleeping, and he said to Peter, "So you could not keep watch with me for one hour?
Keep watch and pray so that you do not enter into testing. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak."
Again, going away a second time, he prayed, saying, "My Father, if this cannot pass unless I drink it, let your will be done."
And coming back again, he found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.
And leaving them, he went away again and prayed a third time, saying the same words once more.
Then he came to the disciples and said to them, "Are you still sleeping and resting? Look—the hour has drawn near, and the Son of Man is being handed over into the hands of sinners.
Get up, let us go. Look—the one handing me over has drawn near."
And while he was still speaking, suddenly Judas, one of the twelve, arrived, and with him a large crowd with swords and clubs, from the chief priests and elders of the people.
Now the one handing him over had given them a sign, saying, "The one I kiss—he is the one. Seize him."
And immediately coming to Jesus, he said, "Greetings, Rabbi!" and kissed him warmly.
Jesus said to him, "Friend, do what you came for." Then they came forward, laid hands on Jesus, and seized him.
And suddenly one of those with Jesus stretched out his hand, drew his sword, and struck the servant of the high priest, cutting off his ear.
Then Jesus said to him, "Return your sword to its place, for all who take up the sword will perish by the sword.
Or do you think that I cannot call upon my Father, and he will at once provide me with more than twelve legions of angels?
But how then would the scriptures be fulfilled, that it must happen this way?"
At that hour Jesus said to the crowds, "Have you come out with swords and clubs to arrest me as though I were a rebel? Day after day I sat in the temple teaching, and you did not seize me.
But all this has happened so that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled." Then all the disciples abandoned him and fled.
Those who had seized Jesus led him away to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and the elders had gathered.
Peter was following him at a distance, as far as the courtyard of the high priest, and going inside, he sat with the attendants to see the outcome.
Now the chief priests and the whole council were seeking false testimony against Jesus so that they might put him to death,
but they found none, though many false witnesses came forward. Finally two came forward
and said, "This man said, 'I am able to destroy the sanctuary of God and rebuild it in three days.'"
And the high priest stood up and said to him, "Have you no answer? What is it that these men are testifying against you?"
But Jesus was silent. And the high priest said to him, "I put you under oath by the living God: tell us if you are the Christ, the Son of God."
Jesus said to him, "You have said it. But I tell you, from now on you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of the Power and coming on the clouds of heaven."
Then the high priest tore his robes, saying, "He has blasphemed! What further need do we have of witnesses? Look—now you have heard the blasphemy.
What is your verdict?" They answered, "He deserves death."
Then they spat in his face and struck him with their fists, and some slapped him,
saying, "Prophesy to us, Christ! Who is the one who hit you?"
Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard, and a servant girl came to him, saying, "You also were with Jesus the Galilean."
But he denied it before all of them, saying, "I do not know what you are talking about."
When he went out to the gateway, another servant girl saw him and said to those there, "This man was with Jesus the Nazarene."
And again he denied it with an oath: "I do not know the man."
After a little while, those standing nearby came up and said to Peter, "Surely you are also one of them, for your speech gives you away."
Then he began to invoke curses on himself and to swear, "I do not know the man!" And immediately a rooster crowed.
And Peter remembered the word Jesus had spoken: "Before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times." And going outside, he wept bitterly.

chapters.notes:
**"Handed over" (vv. 2, 15, 16, 21, 23, 24, 25, 45, 46, 48)**: The Greek παραδίδωμι appears throughout this chapter like a refrain. While "betray" is common in English translations, the Greek term is more neutral—it means to hand over, deliver, or transfer. "Betray" adds moral judgment the Greek doesn't inherently carry. The repeated use of this one verb ties together Jesus's prophecy, Judas's action, and the theological reality that Jesus is being delivered into human hands according to divine purpose.

**"Lord" vs. "Rabbi" (vv. 22, 25, 49)**: The disciples address Jesus as κύριε ("Lord"), but Judas alone uses ῥαββί ("Rabbi"). This subtle distinction in Matthew's Greek may signal Judas's detachment—he uses the formal address of a student to teacher rather than the disciples' confession of Jesus's lordship.

**"Beautiful deed" (v. 10)**: The Greek καλόν means both "good" and "beautiful." The woman's action is not merely morally good but fitting, appropriate, even aesthetically right for the moment. "Beautiful" captures this richer sense.

**"A certain man" (v. 18)**: The unusual τὸν δεῖνα ("a certain someone" or "so-and-so") is left deliberately vague in the Greek. This seems to be Matthew's way of indicating that Jesus named a specific person whose identity was either unknown to readers or deliberately withheld.

**"Fall away" (vv. 31, 33)**: The Greek σκανδαλίζω relates to a snare or stumbling block. "Be offended" (a common rendering) is too weak; "fall away" captures the sense of being caused to stumble in faith and abandon Jesus.

**"Testing" (v. 41)**: Greek πειρασμός means trial or testing, not merely "temptation" in the modern sense of enticement to minor vice. Jesus warns against entering a time of severe testing that might break their faithfulness.

**"Deeply distressed" (v. 37)**: The Greek ἀδημονεῖν suggests severe anguish, restless anxiety, and troubled distress—stronger than ordinary sadness.

**"Overwhelmed with sorrow" (v. 38)**: Greek περίλυπος ("surrounded by grief") echoes the Psalms (42:5, 11; 43:5 LXX), where the psalmist asks, "Why are you cast down, O my soul?"

**"Friend, do what you came for" (v. 50)**: The Greek ἐφ᾽ ὃ πάρει is notoriously difficult. It could be a question ("Why have you come?") or a command ("Do what you came for"). The latter fits better with the immediate action that follows. Ἑταῖρε ("friend, companion") is notably used elsewhere in Matthew for those in ambiguous or adversarial positions (20:13; 22:12).

**"Kissed him warmly" (v. 49)**: The intensified verb κατεφίλησεν suggests an effusive or fervent kiss, adding to the grotesque irony of the betrayal.

**"Rebel" (v. 55)**: Greek λῃστής can mean robber but also armed insurgent or revolutionary. Jesus's point is that they've come armed as if to capture a dangerous insurrectionist, not a teacher who sat openly in the temple.

**"Sanctuary" (v. 61)**: Greek ναός refers specifically to the inner temple building, the sacred structure itself, not the broader temple complex (ἱερόν).

**"The Power" (v. 64)**: Jesus uses "the Power" (τῆς δυνάμεως) as a reverential circumlocution for God, avoiding the divine name while alluding to Psalm 110:1 and Daniel 7:13.

verses.text: When morning came, all the chief priests and the elders of the people held a council against Jesus in order to put him to death.
They bound him, led him away, and handed him over to Pilate the governor.
Then Judas, the one who had handed him over, seeing that Jesus had been condemned, was seized with remorse and returned the thirty silver coins to the chief priests and elders,
saying, "I have sinned by handing over innocent blood." But they said, "What is that to us? That is your concern."
And throwing the silver coins into the sanctuary, he withdrew. Then he went away and hanged himself.
The chief priests took the silver coins and said, "It is not lawful to put them into the temple treasury, since it is the price of blood."
So after holding a council, they used the coins to purchase the Potter's Field as a burial place for foreigners.
For this reason that field has been called the Field of Blood to this day.
Then what was spoken through Jeremiah the prophet was fulfilled: "And they took the thirty silver coins, the price of the one whose price was set, the price set by the sons of Israel,
and they gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord directed me."
Now Jesus stood before the governor, and the governor questioned him, saying, "Are you the King of the Jews?" Jesus said, "You are saying it."
And while he was being accused by the chief priests and elders, he answered nothing.
Then Pilate said to him, "Do you not hear how many things they are testifying against you?"
But he did not answer him regarding even a single charge, so that the governor was greatly amazed.
Now at the festival, the governor was accustomed to release one prisoner to the crowd—whomever they wanted.
At that time they had a notorious prisoner called Jesus Barabbas.
So when they had gathered, Pilate said to them, "Whom do you want me to release to you: Jesus Barabbas, or Jesus who is called the Messiah?"
For he knew that they had handed him over out of envy.
While he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent word to him: "Have nothing to do with that righteous man, for I have suffered greatly today because of a dream about him."
But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the crowds to ask for Barabbas and to have Jesus destroyed.
The governor responded and said to them, "Which of the two do you want me to release to you?" They said, "Barabbas."
Pilate said to them, "Then what should I do with Jesus who is called the Messiah?" They all said, "Let him be crucified!"
He said, "Why? What evil has he done?" But they shouted all the more, "Let him be crucified!"

When Pilate saw that he was accomplishing nothing but rather that an uproar was starting, he took water and washed his hands before the crowd, saying, "I am innocent of this man's blood. You will see to it."
And all the people answered, "His blood be on us and on our children!"
Then he released Barabbas to them, and after having Jesus flogged, he handed him over to be crucified.
Then the governor's soldiers took Jesus into the praetorium and gathered the whole cohort around him.
They stripped him and put a scarlet military cloak on him,
and having woven a crown out of thorns, they placed it on his head, and a reed in his right hand. And falling on their knees before him, they mocked him, saying, "Hail, King of the Jews!"
They spit on him, took the reed, and kept striking him on the head.
And when they had finished mocking him, they stripped off the cloak and put his own garments on him and led him away to crucify him.
As they were going out, they found a man from Cyrene named Simon. They pressed him into service to carry his cross.
And when they came to the place called Golgotha, which means Place of a Skull,
they gave him wine mixed with gall to drink. But after tasting it, he refused to drink.
When they had crucified him, they divided his garments among themselves by casting lots.
Then they sat down and kept guard over him there.
Above his head they placed the written charge against him: "This is Jesus, the King of the Jews."
Then two bandits were crucified with him, one on his right and one on his left.
Those passing by were reviling him, shaking their heads
and saying, "You who would destroy the sanctuary and rebuild it in three days—save yourself! If you are the Son of God, come down from the cross!"
Likewise the chief priests, along with the scribes and elders, mocked him, saying,
"He saved others; he cannot save himself! He is the King of Israel—let him come down now from the cross, and we will believe in him.
He has put his trust in God—let God rescue him now if he wants him. For he said, 'I am the Son of God.'"
In the same way, the bandits who were crucified with him also kept insulting him.
From the sixth hour, darkness came over all the land until the ninth hour.
About the ninth hour, Jesus cried out with a loud voice, "Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?"—that is, "My God, my God, why have you abandoned me?"
Some of those standing there heard this and said, "This man is calling for Elijah."
Immediately one of them ran and took a sponge, filled it with sour wine, put it on a reed, and began giving him a drink.
But the others said, "Wait—let us see if Elijah comes to save him."
Then Jesus cried out again with a loud voice and released his spirit.
And look—the curtain of the sanctuary was torn in two from top to bottom, the earth shook, and the rocks were split apart.
The tombs were opened, and many bodies of the holy ones who had fallen asleep were raised.
Coming out of the tombs after his resurrection, they entered the holy city and appeared to many.
When the centurion and those with him who were guarding Jesus saw the earthquake and the things that had happened, they were terrified and said, "Truly this man was God's Son!"
Many women were there, watching from a distance—women who had followed Jesus from Galilee, serving him.
Among them were Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
When evening came, a wealthy man from Arimathea arrived, named Joseph, who had himself become a disciple of Jesus.
This man approached Pilate and requested the body of Jesus. Then Pilate ordered it to be released.
Joseph took the body and wrapped it in clean linen cloth,
and placed it in his own new tomb, which he had cut into the rock. After rolling a large stone against the entrance of the tomb, he departed.
Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were there, sitting opposite the tomb.
On the next day, which is after the Preparation, the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered before Pilate,
saying, "Sir, we remember that while he was still alive, that deceiver said, 'After three days I will be raised.'

Therefore, order the tomb to be made secure until the third day, lest his disciples come and steal him and tell the people, 'He has been raised from the dead.' Then the last deception would be worse than the first."
Pilate said to them, "You have a guard. Go and make it as secure as you know how."
So they went and made the tomb secure by sealing the stone, along with the guard.

chapters.notes:
**"Seized with remorse" (v. 3)**: The Greek μεταμεληθείς is distinct from the word for repentance (μετάνοια). It denotes regret or remorse over consequences rather than genuine transformation of heart. Judas felt the weight of what he had done without experiencing true repentance.

**"That is your concern" (v. 4) / "You will see to it" (v. 24)**: Both translate forms of σὺ ὄψῃ/ὄψεσθε—an idiom placing responsibility on the other party. The ironic repetition connects Judas's guilt-deflection back onto the priests with the priests' guilt-deflection onto Pilate.

**"Sanctuary" vs. "temple" (vv. 5, 40, 51)**: Greek distinguishes ναός (the sanctuary proper, including the Holy Place and Holy of Holies) from ἱερόν (the entire temple complex). Judas throws the coins into the sacred sanctuary itself; the curtain that tears is the sanctuary curtain. This precision matters theologically.

**"Jesus Barabbas" (vv. 16-17)**: Following the SBLGNT, which includes the name "Jesus" for Barabbas based on early manuscript evidence. This creates a stark choice between two men named "Jesus"—one whose name means "son of the father" (Bar-abba).

**"Pressed into service" (v. 32)**: ἠγγάρευσαν is a Persian loanword (via Aramaic) for compulsory requisitioning—the legal right of Roman soldiers to conscript civilians for labor.

**"Bandits" (vv. 38, 44)**: λῃσταί refers to brigands or insurrectionists, not petty thieves (κλέπται). This was the term Josephus used for Jewish rebels against Rome, giving the crucifixion a political dimension.

**"Released his spirit" (v. 50)**: ἀφῆκεν τὸ πνεῦμα suggests a voluntary act of releasing or dismissing, rather than simply "dying." Jesus yields his life deliberately.

**"God's Son" (v. 54)**: The Greek θεοῦ υἱός lacks the definite article, creating ambiguity. The centurion may mean "a divine being's son" in pagan terms, while Matthew's readers would hear the fuller christological confession.

**"Fallen asleep" (v. 52)**: κεκοιμημένων is the standard early Christian euphemism for death, emphasizing its temporary nature for believers.

verses.text: After the Sabbath, as it was dawning toward the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to see the tomb.
And suddenly there was a great earthquake, for an angel of the Lord descended from heaven, came forward, rolled away the stone, and sat upon it.
His appearance was like lightning, and his clothing white as snow.
The guards shook in terror of him and became like dead men.
But the angel spoke to the women: "You need not fear—I know you are looking for Jesus, the crucified one.
He is not here, for he has been raised, just as he said. Come, see the place where he was lying.
Then go quickly and tell his disciples: 'He has been raised from the dead, and look—he is going ahead of you to Galilee. There you will see him.' I have told you."
And they left the tomb quickly, with fear and great joy, and ran to bring the message to his disciples.
And suddenly Jesus met them, saying, "Rejoice!" They came forward, took hold of his feet, and worshiped him.
Then Jesus said to them, "Do not be afraid. Go, tell my brothers to go to Galilee, and there they will see me."
While they were on their way, some of the guard went into the city and reported to the chief priests everything that had happened.
After assembling with the elders and deliberating together, they gave the soldiers a considerable sum of silver,
telling them, "Say this: 'His disciples came at night and stole him while we were sleeping.'
And if this reaches the governor's ears, we will persuade him and keep you out of trouble."
So they took the silver and did as they were instructed. And this story has been spread among the Judeans to this day.
Now the eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain where Jesus had directed them.
When they saw him, they worshiped him—though some hesitated.
And Jesus came forward and spoke to them: "All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.
Go, therefore, and make disciples of all the nations, baptizing them into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,
teaching them to observe everything I have commanded you. And look—I am with you all the days until the completion of the age."

chapters.notes:
**"Shook" (v. 4)**: The Greek ἐσείσθησαν shares the same root as σεισμός ("earthquake") in verse 2. Matthew creates deliberate wordplay: the earth quakes, and then the guards quake. The same cosmic power that moves the earth paralyzes those who oppose the resurrection.

**"You need not fear" (v. 5)**: The Greek includes an emphatic ὑμεῖς ("you yourselves"), creating a contrast with the guards who rightly trembled. The angel distinguishes between those seeking Jesus and those guarding against him.

**"He has been raised" (v. 6, 7)**: The Greek ἠγέρθη is passive voice—a theological passive indicating that God raised Jesus. This is not merely "he rose" (active) but "he was raised" by divine action.

**"Rejoice!" (v. 9)**: The Greek Χαίρετε was a common greeting (like "hello"), but it literally means "rejoice." In this context—the women fleeing a tomb with "great joy"—the literal sense resonates. Jesus's first word to them after resurrection is an invitation to joy.

**"My brothers" (v. 10)**: Jesus calls the disciples τοῖς ἀδελφοῖς μου. This is theologically significant—after the disciples abandoned him, Jesus does not call them "my disciples" but "my brothers," signaling restored relationship.

**"Hesitated" (v. 17)**: The Greek ἐδίστασαν appears only here and in Matthew 14:31 (Peter on the water). It suggests wavering or being of two minds rather than outright disbelief—a more nuanced response than simple "doubt."

**"Into the name" (v. 19)**: The preposition εἰς ("into") rather than ἐν ("in") suggests incorporation—being baptized into union with and belonging to the triune God, not merely invoking a name over someone.

**"Completion of the age" (v. 20)**: The Greek συντελείας τοῦ αἰῶνος refers to the consummation or fulfillment of the present age, not merely its termination. "Completion" captures this sense of purposeful culmination.
